Please!, they wouldn't last a week while imbibing before and/or during class time. Happy party scene at the end was pure dumb.

reviews.review_title: A mix of genius and cliché
reviews.content: The screenplay is so detailed and the characters so well done that I thought it was one of those "based on a book" movies. It is not. The direction is good, the acting terrific, the story quite educative. But not everything is rosy.As others have noticed, the story of four high school teachers trying out a theory that moderate alcohol in the blood makes one more open and creative goes wrong in the most predictable ways, making it hard not to interpret the film as a moralistic tale of dubious intentions. I mean, is the story realistic? Quite so. It's quite possible that this could happen. Unfortunately it happens bluntly, with no finesse and seems to damn any drinker to social suicide. Even the positive effects come out of nowhere, only to then be replaced by really negative ones, following the tired formula that nothing good comes for free.In a way, it's an unfunny Trainspotting, where drugs are replaced with alcohol, with remarkably similar effects. It is impossible to not take the film as a critique of the Danish propensity for heavy drinking, which diminishes the great performance of the lead actors a little.Bottom line: a midlife crisis examination of alcoholism with great performances but a formulaically moralistic viewpoint that takes away from the experience.

'Another Round (2020)' is a Danish film about four middle-aged teachers who, discontent with their stagnant lives, decide to experiment with maintaining a constant level of alcohol (0.05%) in their blood at all times. What starts out as intoxicating soon becomes dangerous, as their purely scientific trial threatens to devolve into all-out alcoholism. The different men handle their booze in different ways, though they all inevitably fly too close to the sun at one point or another. I've seen some accusations that the film condones substance abuse, but I don't think that's the case. Though it doesn't have an overt anti-alcohol message, it makes sure to show both the good and the bad of its focal fluid and ultimately advocates for moderation above all else. Plus, its teenage characters are supposed to be either seventeen or eighteen and the legal age for buying alcohol in Denmark is sixteen. Though I don't think it's a good idea for children to consume what's, essentially, poison, I think this flick is just honest to the society in which its characters and filmmakers live. Basically, this aspect is more of a societal and cultural issue than one specific to this feature. The film isn't a clear-cut morality tale, rather a relatively realistic examination of human emotion in all its imperfect glory. It depicts happiness, sadness, complacency, resentment, enjoyment and anxiety; it runs the gamut of emotion, both in what it depicts and it what it elicits, to craft an unbiased portrait of its subjects that resonates on a surprisingly deep level. Its bittersweet final scene, which mixes melancholy with jubilation in a bizarrely touching way, is a microcosm of its overall nuance. The movie is a touch slow in its second act, but it's typically an entertaining and engaging experience. Its performances are remarkable, too. It's as often funny as it is heartbreaking. Generally, it feels like a grounded and honest experience that manages to be life-affirming without being close to saccharine. It isn't happy, so to speak, just truthful. Truth can be beautiful. 7/10.

Another RoundThis movie cleverly looked at several themes in a semi-humorous way. The lightness of touch of both script and direction belayed it serious undertones and conjectured that middle age can bring on a re-evaluation of where you have arrived in life and the conclusion of this an lead to a potential life crisis.ThemesThe juxtaposition of the students at the beginning of their lives emphasised the jaded and stale reality of the teachers at their time of life.That life crushes you slowly by degree until you are a pale shadow of the person you were or indeed wanted to be.The observation that alcohol removes inhibitions and the "real" you emerges to stalk the earth.The side effect of alcohol is a heightened emotional connection to reality.The teachers experimented with alcohol to assist in bringing back their "better selves", however with the death of their friend, partially due to alcoholism, did they realise the role of alcohol in their lives and that it doesn't need to be all or nothing.Did the movies arrive at conclusions, no, but it thoroughly enjoyed the investigation of the hypothesis. It was all a very simple premise but this movie was inspirational in its execution.I loved this movie but I am not anxious to see it again. For me it's a strong 8 outta 10 for holding my attention.

reviews.review_title: It could have been a Path-Breaking film on Alcohol culture but it opts to play safe with the general theories.

Another Round (2020) :
Brief Review -It could have been a Path-Breaking film on Alcohol culture but it opts to play safe with the general theories. Another Round is a great story by the way, but only if you look at those attractive elements. Rest, it has the same typical old-school-drama on Life. The use of alcoholism was never done like this and that's where the film interests you and at one moment it begins to look like a path-breaking film only to follow the mainstream theories of personality development and acknowledgement of rediscovering that lost joy in busy lifestyle. Four friends, all high school teachers, test a theory that they will improve their lives by maintaining a constant level of alcohol in their blood. With the solid reference of Psychiatrist Finn Skårderud's theories it looks a magnificent idea and till the intermission point it works very impressively too. However, the second half goes to follow the general theories of life such as family issues like parenthood, relationship blunders, extramarital affair and all, along with the typical boring regretful speeches and bla bla. See, it looks uninteresting as hell. I mean, we have seen the same stuff again and again over the years and more effective too, then why the hell this would be path-breaking story falls into the same gutter? That's the last freaking mistake one could have done and unfortunately it is done here. Nevertheless, the rest of the film is worthy enough to grab your attention. Especially, the cinematic brilliance of Vinterberg and fantastic performance of Mads Mikkelsen very well supported by Thomas Bo Larsen, Lars Ranthe and Magnus Millang. Some scenes in the film are simply amazing while some are typically outdated. Overall, a very good film or better say a very good attempt to do something unusual which lacks the outbreaking theories.RATING - 7/10*By - #samthebestest.

reviews.review_title: The answer to all of life's riddles lies at the bottom of a bottle.
reviews.content: Taking risks and taking responsibility can be two sides of the same coin but never seem to mesh in Thomas Vinterberg's ("Far from the Madding Crowd") comedy-drama Another Round, Denmark's submission for Best Foreign Film at the 2021 Oscars. Written by Tobias Lindholm ("The Hunt") and Vinterberg, the premise of the film lies in a dubious theory ascribed to Norwegian psychiatrist Finn Skarderud who asserts that the blood-alcohol content of all human beings is always too low, a 0.05% blood-alcohol content deficit. People would be far more engaged and energetic, he argues, if they maintained a level of 0.10%. In other words, the answer to all of life's riddles lies at the bottom of a bottle.Vinterberg is willing to give the theory a test drive, "We've seen so many movies about how alcohol kills people," he says, "but there's a reason a lot of people drink. It can make you fly." One is tempted to recall the old adage that if God wanted people to fly, he would have given them wings. Willing and eager to test this theory, however, are four middle-aged teachers in a public high school whose zest for life has faded like the afternoon sun: History teacher, Martin (a craggy-faced Mads Mikkelsen, "Arctic"); PE teacher and soccer coach, Tommy (Thomas Bo Larsen, "The Wave"); music teacher, Peter (Lars Ranthe, "Hunting Season"); and psychology teacher, Nikolaj (Magnus Millang, "Heavy Load"), all with seemingly nothing to give their lives true meaning in spite of having advantages that three-quarters of the world's population would beg for.The film begins with a fun drinking game and ends with more drinking fun, but there's a world of pain in between. Vinterberg coaxes excellent performances from his four leading men and we root for them. At the beginning of the experiment which includes drinking while at work during the day, results appear to be 95% effective, though they will soon require a booster shot. Martin, whose history lessons have ranged from dull to comatose, achieves liftoff after a few drinks and engages his students in a fun game of choosing which one of three unnamed people make better role models, the heavy drinkers: Churchill and Hemingway, or the vegetarian, non-drinker Adolf Hitler.For the students in this incongruously small class, Hitler seems to be the obvious choice, one that allows Martin to make the point that the world does not always meet our expectations. Peter inspires his choir to sing from the heart. Tommy instills confidence (and some hitherto unseen soccer skills) in a diminutive youngster known not so endearingly as "Specs," while Nikolaj handles an anxiety-ridden student with tact and understanding, and his dead-on-arrival marriage to Amalie (Helene Reingaard Neumann, "The Command") also becomes revived. Each man responds to the experiment in different ways but the warm friendship and camaraderie of the four men remains constant.Eventually, they decide that if a little alcohol can work such wonders, why not try a little more? Layers of sadness soon bubble up and the men are forced to reevaluate how much satisfaction they have been experiencing in their relationships and in their jobs. As the amount of drinking increases, however, so does the downward spiral and the loss of a job by one teacher after he was caught staggering and mumbling in school. At home, Martin virtually ignores his two sons while his wife Anika (Maria Bonnevie, "Becoming Astrid") works at night. He asks Anika if she thinks he's a bore, a characterization the viewer has long since concluded in the positive. Her reply that "you are not the same person that I once knew" is hardly surprising and the passive and affectless Martin cannot raise enough emotion to tell her that he is leaving, except for a few sudden outbursts of anger on his way out the door. There are more traumas to follow, but overall Vinterberg makes drinking quite an acceptable way to bond and enjoy yourself without the word alcoholism ever coming up.While Another Round examines the tug of war between celebrating life and acting irresponsibly, the film's message is ambiguous. Vinterberg says that he and Lindholm "deliberately avoided having a message." The film he asserts is, "a survey and exploration not only of alcohol usage but of the uncontrollable. It is just a catalyst for talking about being inspired in life." I guess drinking can be a wonderful thing unless it destroys your life and that of those around you. "You find a lot of AA people in the cinemas who feel they've been betrayed," Vinterberg says, "They've seen how bad it can go, and it's an interesting open end, I guess." Do tell.

reviews.review_title: The King of Beers. Just As Good As The First Time I Saw It.
reviews.content: The Good: I loved Another Round when I first saw it, and honestly, I still love it. It might be my favourite film of 2020, to be honest.This movie is really two stories: one is about a group of friends who want to jazz up their lives and embark a very socially unacceptable experiment. The friendship dynamic is unbelievably realistic and well developed. I felt watching this movie that I knew these men and the film really conveys their history and familiarity with one another. The performances are excellent, especially Madds Mikkelsen, who feels so relatable and human here. I don't know, maybe it's my subjective feeling as a young man hoping I can retain friendships like this or maybe it's just objectively well done, but this aspect of the story really gets me.But, I have to be honest, what Another Round is *really* about is Denmark, alcohol, and the Danish drinking culture. The film is really a thesis statement as to how alcohol - for better or worse - is essential to Danish society. This movie depicts the highest of highs and the lowest of lows and instead of shaking his finger disapprovingly, Vinterberg shrugs. "It is what it is," might as well be the motto of this film. Alcohol isn't going anywhere and to ignore why it's been used by people longer than the wheel or the written word is foolish. Some people may find this offensive - I'm sure we all know the evils alcohol has caused as well - but I found it refreshing (pun intended). We're so used to a particular morality with Hollywood films that I really liked how Another Round is more of a celebration of cracking a few cold ones with your friends more than anything else.The cinematography is also outstanding in this movie. Whatever Danish town this is (and I think it's kept purposefully vague), I felt like it was my home by the end of the movie. The environment is so well defined and characterized here; Another Round is both a very personal story and a story about a people and a place. Some of the scenes with these guys just hanging out are so well done that it makes you want to be there with them. It's just awesome, I'm a sucker for well done party scenes.The Bad: So, upon rewatch, I did notice a couple of problems with the movie. The ending is a little under baked; things just sort of fall into place and it wraps up a bit too conveniently. Not that we necessarily need an explanation why Martin's wife has an about face, but it would have been nice for there to be a scene with them reconnecting.A big thing happens at the end that doesn't elicit the reaction you'd imagine from these characters, and personally, I felt it should have been pushed up and then the final third of the movie could be people coming to terms with it. That's just me though, I'm no Vinterberg.The Ugly: Another Round joins Sideways as one of the all time best movies where alcohol is almost a character. I challenge you to watch this and not crave a cold beer or a satisfying glass of wine. It's honestly really hard. To all those who imbibe, maybe a little too much sometimes: Skål!

reviews.review_title: One of the Best Movies of 2020/2021
reviews.content: Danish "Druk", directed deftly by Thomas Vinterberg, is a strongly entertaining commentary on Danish drinking. Mads Mikkelsen shows again why he's Denmark's premier actor with an emotionally complex and strangely painful journey of a man in his "mid-life" crisis that endeavors to embrace alcohol. There's something reminiscent of the British "Full Monty" here reflected in "Druk" - Monty was a lovely movie over 20 years earlier - "Druk" has similar story patterns and camaraderie between its characters. While "Full Monty" was about economic woes, "Druk" goes more beneath the surface and deals with complex emotional problems brought upon by taxing work and family time tug-of-wars. Alcohol seems to strangely save the day to start, although we know where this is leading, as there is always a control issue on the horizon blurring the lines between alcohol dependency and responsible drinkingl There doesn't seem to be an answer, and Vinterberg may not be looking for one. Further it may be an examination into ills, benefits, but indeed pervasiveness. Great drama with well mixed in comedy. 8/10.

At some point we all wonder what sort of impact our life is making. If we "dare" to dance, to fly,... we must first seek and find the "ignition." How fast we push down on the pedal is where survival catapults to artful balance. This film is wholly accessible high art, swaying madly but ever so finely, between poignant and damn hilarious.

I only watched this because the ratings were so high. I didn't know it's not in English & luckily I don't have an issue reading subtitles. This movie is exactly what it says, nothing more. About 4 high school teachers who decide to keep their blood alcohol level at 0.5 by steadily drinking all day until 8pm. I was very disappointed. This is one of those movies that when it ends you're like that's it? There's no point, no moral, nothing to write home about. I will never watch this again nor can I recommend it. One thing I would like to comment on is that I was blown away that the TEACHERS told a couple of their students who were struggling with their grades to drink alcohol before their finals. This is High School. The teachers handed them hard liquor they kept on them at school & told them to belt back a few big swigs off it because it would help them do better on their finals & not to worry they wouldn't tell anyone. What kind of example does this set? Is that really good advice? Is that truly a good habit to get into? Relying on alcohol to solve the issues they'll run into throughout the rest of their life? I don't think so.

SPOILERS:
I agree this is a very good movie but I am shocked at how many reviews mention how funny it is-I found it mostly sad! And the ending has me confused. I thought they were going to tone down the drinking after Tommy's death, and Martin's wife saw him sober at their last meeting. I assumed that was one of the reasons she decided to take him back. But when he finds that out, he continues to drink and dances that incredible dance at the end, and that tells me he's choosing alcohol over her. Most reviews here talk about a happy ending, but I thought it was tragic that he chose to drink instead of saving his marriage.

Vinterberg and Mikkelsen did it again! It's a totally different story and tone here, but Another Round is as good as The Hunt imo.Another difficult thematic to approach, another bunch of scenes that will make you think about it and a lot of not so politically correct scenes/statements again. Another Round feels fresh, feels real and shows one more time that Vinterbeg and Mikkelsen are not afraid of critics while creating their art.One of the best of the year and another amazing interpretation by Mads Mikkelsen (a shame that 99.9% of the time, the Academy only considers foreign movies for a single category, he deserved to be on the best actor discussion and the movie on the best picture).

reviews.review_title: Interesting, but the ending did not resonate
reviews.content: Films have a tendency to fall on one of 2 sides when their subject matter is drinking, partying and alchoholism - (1) "They're just a bunch of partying fun people" or (2) "They're drinking to cover up emotions they don't want to deal with and, eventually, it will lead to their ruin".Danish Director Thomas Vinterberg was the surprise Oscar nominee for his direction in the film ANOTHER ROUND (a film he also co-wrote) as he attempted the noble feat of straddling these two sides.And...the result is an admirable attempt that falls just shy of being good.Starring the great Mads Mikkelsen (the villain in the first DR. STRANGE film), ANOTHER ROUND tells the tale of 4 Danish High School teachers who are stuck in a rut (call it a mid-life crisis) and come up with the idea of being slightly drunk all of the time to elevate their lives.The first half of the film flirts with "Frat Boy Party" territory as the 4 friends embark on the quest to see if staying slightly drunk elevates them. The results are quite mixed with moments of joy and triumph mixed in with some cringe-inducing moments. But then Vinterberg mines the "dark side" of alcoholism and the film takes a dark - and more interesting turn - only to have another turn at the end that just didn't work for me.Mikkelsen, of course, is quite good in the central role of Martin - the family man in mid-life depression crisis that kicks into "Frat Boy" mode when drinking "just enough". His character switches back and forth between these 2 modes and Mikkelsen handles these changes like the terrific actor that he is.His 3 friends played by Magnus Millang, Lars Ranthe and Thomas Bo Larson are all equally depressed and switch back and forth right along with Martin. Unfortunately, none of these 3 have the "it" factor of Mikkelsen, so are really kept in his shadow - with the possible exception of a few moments by Larson.This is the first film I have seen from Vinterberg, but what I have read about him is that this film pretty much sums up his career. An interesting idea, told fairly well with an ending that doesn't really land. And that's what I thought of this film. I'm glad I saw it, but it will fade after a time, as the ending just didn't provide enough depth to keep ANOTHER ROUND with me for long.Letter Grade: B-6 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

reviews.review_title: One of the best films I've seen in a long time
reviews.content: This movie is an analogy for drinking itself. There are high highs, and very low lows. But the crux of the message, to me, was that we all feel the same things. We experience happiness, struggle, ruts, sadness, friendship, melancholy, and numbness the same way. We often treat it the same way too, which is to try and escape from our reality. But in the end, the things that matter will always be there, we just sometimes need a different lens to view them through, in this film that lens is alcohol. For better or worse.Absolutely brilliant!

reviews.review_title: Not really funny, although it was a funny idea of letting teachers drink a lot to see if their educative skills would improve...
reviews.content: It was a funny idea of making a movie about 4 teachers who try to find out if they would become better teachers when they are drunk. But the execution of this promising idea is rather dull, because we only get to see middle aged men getting a bit drunker every other week. No real dramas, no real funny events occur, they just get a little bit more drunk, when they drink more. Oh yes, the schoolkids loved it. Of course...Waste of Mads Mikkelsen's talents, I honestly dont know what he did in this picture. Quite lame..Not any good? Well, for those who love to find excuses to drink a lot, this movie might reinforce their beliefs that drinking is good.The bad: it's rather tedious to watch. Lacking punch in story development, because nothing else happens in this movie besides seeing 4 teachers get a bit drunk.

Another Round (original title Druk) is one of the best movies I have seen this year.Four close middle aged friends decide to test the theory that the quality of life improves while maintaining a constant level of alcohol in your blood.Mikkelsen once again shows his talents and is supported by a great cast. The story is original and not too moralizing. On the contrary to be honest: I don't think the AA will be too positive about this film.The dance sequence plus the freeze-frame ending, also gave me the goosebumps, instant classic for me!

Interesting concept about life, education, alcohol and death. I think actors are great on their roles also the original idea is well executed. But, over everything is Mads Mikelsen what an underrated actor by Hollywood. So, overall a great refreshing movie/concept.

reviews.review_title: What life dissatisfaction can cause to some people.
reviews.content: Thomas Vinterberg is a director capable of turning the most boring and ordinary subject into a compelling plot. Martin, is a high school teacher that basically lost any kind of motivation. He does not enjoy his job anymore, he cannot communicate with his family and he feels so distant from his wife. One day he decides to do an experiment with his colleagues: drinking a little bit of alcohol during the day, in order to be more energetic. The first part is basically a comedy: a group of friends finding purpose in life again. There are many funny scenes that made me laugh. Then, the light-hearted tone becomes darker, things get out of hand and in the second part, the film depicts the dramatic consequences of their choices.I think that the director does a really good job exploring which may be some of the causes for alcohol addiction, how this can influence your everyday life and people around you. The script really deepens characters and their friendship; I felt really attached to them. I think that there was not one single scene wasted, everything fit just perfectly. The cast is phenomenal and it is composed by pretty big names of Danish cinema: Mads Mikkelsen and Thomas Larsen are two of the most famous actors in the industry, but they did not shadow Magnus Millang and Lars Ranthe, who are as good. Every single actor bringed something to the table, and contributed to tell an emotional story. The very last scene with the song performed by Scarlet Pleasure is one of the most beautiful things that I have watched this year.I absolutely enjoyed "Another Round". This movie represents the return of the roots for Mikkelsen, in every sense. I am genuinely happy that after the success obtained through Hollywood blockbusters, he came back to his motherland, promoting, in a way, Danish cinema.

Everything in this movie is very predictable, to the point it becomes very boring.
You'd think that the insights from this movie would make up for this, but no, this movie is pretty shallow.
I guess teenagers would like it because there is some amount of drinnking and partying.

reviews.review_title: Drink alcohol but don't be alcoholic
reviews.content: It has an interesting subject. People want to get drunk after the movie ;) Mads Mikkelsen did a great job. Mr. Vinterberg also did a good job. The dance scene was great. Drink alcohol but don't be alcoholic.

reviews.review_title: A film about the positive and negative sides of the use of alcohol.
reviews.content: Druk is a new comedy drama directed and written in part by Thomas Vinterberg, the director of The Hunt.In the film, Martin (Mads Mikkelsen) and three other colleagues decide to test the theory that a modest amount of alcohol in the blood can expand your mind during everyday life. This way you can reduce problems and think more creatively. The four high school teachers know how to teach in an inventive and more relaxed way. As the four drink more and more often, they gradually learn that there is also a negative side to drinking alcohol. They have to determine how far they are willing to go for their experiment, before things get too out of hand.Because the Danish director comes from the country that last year had one of the highest percentages of alcohol use among teenagers in the world, he tries to show with this film what the consequences of alcohol can be. Despite the fact that they try to bring out the consequences of alcohol with this film, they show in a well-balanced way what both the positive and negative sides of the use of alcohol can be. In this way, as a viewer, you get the chance to fill in how you think about alcohol until the end of the film without feeling bad about it.The four leading roles of the film not only come across as colleagues but also as good friends of each other. They continue to support each other during their experiment, but also when one of the four has a personal life. Unfortunately, all four are not presented with the same amount of personal information, so as a viewer you care a bit more about one than the other. All four also manage to convey in a believable way that their characters are experimenting with alcohol without doing it in an exaggerated way.

"I could use a higher BAC to get a little more self-confidence."Another Round is Thomas Vinterberg's newest film about four friends, all high school teachers, testing a theory that they will improve their lives by maintaining a constant level of alcohol in their blood. I'm not super familiar with his other films other than knowing they're critically praised. So this was basically my first Vinterberg film. I gotta say I'm really impressed. Another Round is a fun and dramatic film that goes to places you wouldn't expect. Leading the film, Mads Mikkelsen gives us a great performance. I really enjoyed his character and what he's going through. The same for the other three. They're all doing this experiment for some fun but they have issues to deal with already. The constant drinking is only adding up to it. The most intriguing part was seeing what consequences would arise amidst all the fun. The comedy lands well and I chuckled a few times. But the drama behind it all exceeded my expectations. The last act had me itching to see what would come up next.Thomas Vinterberg is a great director. Just by watching this film, I am really interested in his other works. He has a refreshing sort of approach but reminds us of what we have to deal with by having a little fun, even if it's illegal. The beginning didn't quite hook me in. I thought by that I would just feel like it would just be good rather than the raving reviews. After a while, it really starts to pick up and I didn't want to stop. The portrayal of this growing alcoholism is good. They didn't pose it as a good or bad thing. Rather it's a neutral view of what it's like and how it affects people differently. Each of the characters have a different reaction. I'm glad there's variation and not just them getting flat out drunk the whole time. And the way the film concludes is a great ending. I don't want to spoil but it just really works. There's not much to digest and analyze. All that needs to be said is Another Round is a great film and another showcasing the best of 2020.

As many have noted, a fine film about the slide into middle age, loss of youth, hope and dreams,
discovery of the bottle. Very well acted and directed, very watchable despite the discomfort of seeing people fail, with a ray of hope just at the end to give that high we need. How long will the hero's luck last? The film quotes Kierkegaard, a noble quote about the recognition of one's own failures necessary to loving others. It might also have quoted Kafka: there is infinite hope in the universe, but not for us.

Not to play into the trap of basing my evaluation of a movie on expectations, but I did hope for something more substantial given its high acclaim, including an unusual Best Directing Oscar nomination for Thomas Vinterberg, to go along with its International Film nom, the latter of which it'll likely win. I also find it odd that the title, "Druk," is called "Another Round" in English, which has a celebratory ring to it, but literally translates to "Binge Drinking," with its obviously more negative connotations. Appropriately enough, then, "Druk" manages a balancing act, wobbly though it may be, between those two interpretations. It's not a maudlin lecture on the dangers of the devil's drink, nor some crapulous Hollywood-type celebration of alcoholism (say, "Old School" (2003)). It lies passed out somewhere in between, tipsy in its veering one way or another variously, but ultimately avoiding the fate of more insufferable drunkards.But for naught it would seem, or at least nothing more than another mid-life crisis, male bonding flick--an entire genre I, for one, could do without, although I'm sure I would've enjoyed it more if I were drinking, too.... Anyways, Mads Mikkelsen carries the movie. None of the other characters are remarkable, and one hardly cares about the students for which the drunk teachers oversee their education. The supposed research paper they plan to write of their experience and its flimsy philosophical grounding is a scientifically-slapdash joke to begin with. Personally, though, I have no doubt some could perform better, especially simple tasks easier than driving, such as high-school teaching, while intoxicated. I assume some of my teachers were day drinkers, or at least I doubt they'd be any worse at their jobs had they been, but that's neither here nor there.There's enough here to like, however, to make for a fairly entertaining picture, if hardly life affirming or any other such thing that it's been advertised as. Mikkelsen is a fine actor with a handsome face. There are funny moments. We do eventually get to see Mikkelsen show off those dance moves, and the camera does well to follow along. It's the same for the movie, I suppose, as it's for the marital advice the friends share, about the little things making the difference.One of them that especially stood out to me were the text messages. It seems that cinema still hasn't quite figured out how to visualize texting on screen, let alone depict a human race that's increasingly paralyzed by constant phone staring. Put away the phones, as the lecturer must recite every class. Regardless, this features the best solution to the problem I've yet seen, and the protagonist steps away to check his texts instead of insulting his friends with his distracted glowing face. Text merely appears upon an otherwise black screen. Simple and elegant, and it also reminds me of how silent films handled communication in the first place. Get me "Druk" any day over that Emoji-vomit sequence in "Crazy Rich Asians" (2018) and all the movies in between that can't figure out how to integrate text without it being a nuisance. A rare case of drinking and texting being a good idea.

Interesting film about the effects alcohol can have on us human beings, especially when taken to extremesAbsorbing drama though with terrific acting by the four males affected: Mikkelsen,Larsen,Millang & Ranthe. Maria Bonnevie was also good.

Another Round is an incredible comedy drama that's extremely funny and poignant, skillfully exploring the highs and lows of drinking alcohol. Mads Mikkelsen gives a phenomenal lead performance and Thomas Bo Larsen, Lars Ranthe and Magnus Millang are all incredible with fantastic chemistry. Thomas Vinterberg's direction is excellent, it's extremely well filmed and well paced. The music by Mikkel Maltha and the soundtrack are fantastic.

I went into this movie expecting a full-blown comedy and was surprised by how much heart this film has. There are hilarious moments, inspiring moments, heart-warming moments,, and moments that had me dripping snot and ugly crying. It's not an overly complicated story, which serves the film well -- you get to know and empathize with each character without being burdened with too busy or involved of a plot. It's a classic tale of too much of a good thing; eventually, you must reap what you sow. If you are a fan of character dramas and dark (but not TOO dark) comedies, this is a must-watch. I really can't say enough good things about it.

reviews.review_title: Impossible not to crave a drink while watching
reviews.content: Within thirty minutes of starting "Another Round," I found myself cracking open a bottle of bourbon and pouring myself a glass. I didn't get nearly as drunk as the characters who inhabit this world, and luckily, I didn't need to in order to enjoy this movie."Another Round" is an excellent drama and character study, following the lives of four high school teachers who decide to see if maintaining a constant level of alcohol in their blood from morning to 8 p.m. will improve their lives, both personally and professionally. And if you think that premise is the start to a whimsical, lighthearted adventure, you'd be half right. From celebratory binges with friends to late night tears over beers, "Another Round" demonstrates people's relationship with alcohol, in all of its beauty and destruction.Mads Mikkelsen was pitch-perfect as a professor who is unsatisfied with his life, seeking solace in the bottle. Displaying a vulnerability and quiet desperation, it is fun to watch his transformation to a confident teacher, husband, and friend once he partakes in his pick of poison. Mads is always great in dramatic roles, and it's no different here. There is one incredibly intense scene where he confronts his wife over something while they are eating dinner which does a fantastic job of showing Mads desperately trying to hold on and have some semblance of control over his personal life. Is alcohol his savior, imprisoner, or both?Thomas Vinterberg does great work in directing little character moments, showing how different each person's relationship with alcohol is. From a student potentially having a shot or two to relieve anxiety during class to professors who partake to improve their teaching abilities, the movie is ever fascinating, never portraying alcohol as good or bad - it simply exists, and it's up to each individual person how they choose to use it. The most interesting part of the movie for me was seeing how each character's life begins to subtlety improve as their drinking increases - at least at first. They become more confident professors, breathing new life into their classes and enriching their students' educational experiences. But, the party must end at some point, and "Another Round" also shows the tragic effects of alcohol abuse as well."Another Round" is an excellent drama that will leave you thinking well after the credits roll. You might relate to the characters and their plight, or you might find them detestable drunks. Regardless, you're sure to have at least a moderately good time with this movie, and if you don't, the performances and drama will surely be enough to hold your interest.

I'm not sure what on earth to make of this near ridiculous after school special about the dangers of alcohol.The point of the movie seems to be that drinking literally constantly in an effort to keep your blood alcohol level at a slightly elevated threshold is a bad thing. Well ok then. Glad we got that settled. Seriously, this film is like something you would have seen in the 1940s, when Hollywood decided that it was brave enough to acknowledge things like alcoholism. Wait, this movie WAS made in the 1940s, and it was called "The Lost Weekend."Mads Mikkelsen is a good actor, and he just about pulls off the overwrought material he's given here, but only just about. When the movie isn't wallowing in its "Reefer Madness" hysterics about alcohol consumption, it's wallowing instead in the mid-life crises of a bunch of well off white men, and I just. Didn't. Care.This is not the first Danish film to leave me befuddled, and I've actually been to Denmark twice and have close Danish friends. But this is the third Danish film after "The Hunt" and "A Hijacking" that has left me scratching my head and thinking, "Huh?" There are clearly some cultural differences that I simply don't fully understand.Grade: B.

Martin (Mads Mikkelsen) pines for his fun-loving hard-drinking youth. As an older man, he's a boring high school history teacher. His life has gone stale and his students hate him. After a night of heavy drinking, he and three other teachers decide to do rigorous drinking as an 'experiment'.Let me do the ending first. It's the big scene of the movie. I get the exuberance but I don't like the acrobatics. He's drunk, right? He can't be doing a dance number. At the same time, I get doing a dance to end the movie. Like the rest, I like the idea of it a little more than the actual thing. I like the concept of the experiment but if that's the case, they should exaggerate it by doing it scientifically. They would make up rules and keep careful logs. This is an interesting idea and it has the great Mads doing drunk acting. It's certainly an intriguing film.

There is only one word for this movie and it is - Brilliant.
Mads MIkkelsen keeps making better and better roles. But here you dont see him playing . You see him living. You see ordinary man living but you also see it so clearly , so naturally presented as at the end you almost think that if you were not in his shoes before, you definitely will be at some point in your life. What I can guarantee is that the votes under 10 are surely coming from people that are not fans of Scandic cinematography. But if you are- dont hesitate to watch this movie.
And rate it. If not for else (while there is plenty for), then for Mads. If I was Jeremy Clarkson i would simply say - Astonishing.

reviews.review_title: Strong Lead Mads Mikkelsen in Dark Comedy about Drinking Theory, Midlife Anxieties
reviews.content: "Another Round - Druk" is the latest film from Danish director and Dogme 95 movement co-founder, Thomas Vinterberg ("The Hunt," "Far From the Madding Crowd"). "Another Round" is a dark comedy following the lives of four high school teachers in Denmark going through their own individual midlife anxieties. To loosen up, the four men decide to test a theory they found that states life can improve by spending the day slightly drunk, at a constant alcohol level of 0.05. The film features a strong, magnificent, emotionally wrenching lead performance from Mads Mikkelsen (Le Chiffre in 2006's, "Casino Royale"; Hannibal Lecter in NBC TV drama, "Hannibal") as history teacher, Martin.

What can one even say about a film like this? Vinterberg absolutely nailed the direction. The film was so well written, the acting was absolutely superb, and the characters were all believable, and so true to life.This is a movie that was made by adults, for adults. Mads Mikkelsen gave another one of his master classes in acting, and the rest of the ensemble cast was wonderful. I just do not know how you can improve on a movie like this. The end was icing on the cake. Mads may be one of the best actors of this generation.
And unusual. Really worth watching if you want to see a contrast to all the main stream pop corn superhero movies. Funny, sad, emotional, touching. And superb acting.

reviews.review_title: My own 0.05% experiment is still in progress !!
reviews.content:
My interest in Druk grew more only after the movie won an academy award for the best international feature. The movie has a pretty simple storyline of four middle aged friends, who happen to work at the same place,
decide to carry out an interesting experiment with alcohol, which requires them to drink during work hours.As the narrative progresses, "Druk"draws you in with its complexities. Layers of sentiments and human behavior begin to peel away as the four men lose their inhibitions and bringing forth some very raw emotions. Director Thomas Vinterberg gives us a film about living life and he conveys it in equal measures of subtlety, sadness and exhilaration.Cinematography is a mixed bag throughout the movie, it oscillates between some great close ups in the dark to some over-lit bright shots facing the window panes. Screenplay is simple and straightforward, but a bit boring in the middle to support a 117 minute runtime but it pretty much makes it better towards the end. Editing is very raw and bland for my liking but does the job. Production design, costumes and makeup were decent. Music has some good and some bad bits and may not cater to everyone's taste. On the acting front Mads Mikkelson, as the gloomy, listless Martin who goes through many shades of transformation, is simply brilliant. Thomas Bo Larsen, Lars Ranthe and Magnus Millang also pull in good performances.Overall, Director Thomas Vinterberg gets most of the things right in this rather slightly dull affair, which promises a lot in the beginning but goes flat midway. The movie targeted at a 40+ age groups and may not impact to people younger than the mid thirties as much. But As the film draws to its dying moments, In a burst of infectious, joyous energy exuded by Mikkelson in a dance sequence which almost feels exuberant, one realizes that there are no sweeping judgements or any real closure being served here. 6.9 stars out of 10 for running an interesting experiment and celebrating friendship.

Another Round is one of best films from new realeses that i saw this year and before few days i didnt even know that this film exists and that it will be a great time for me.Story here is very simple but also very deep and it shows us how alcohol works and how many different sensetions it can give us.We are watching people being happy and relaxed because of it and how they look like they are finally enjoying their lifes,but there are also parts were we are seeing how alcohol can also easily destroy families and take lifes from us but in end this film ended on positive note which is good to me

Another one of my favourite 2020 films. Again proving that it was a great year for film. Vinterberg integrates depressing subject matter with comedy perfectly, I haven't laughed so much in a long time.Each of the four main actors performances are great, they act drunk incredibly and give nuanced performances. Subtle emotes and raw emotion. Mads Mikkelsen stands out as expected, his character is also the most well defined.Comments on drinking culture, mental illness and the psychology surrounding addiction. I'm really interested in this kind of thing so I'm glad it was incorporated.It's well made and well shot. Ellipses are used frequently and effectively. I liked the music, I wasn't too big on the track 'what a life' at first but I've come around to it since, it's not great music but it's groovy enough to get my toes tapping and most importantly it felt liberating. I love Franz Schubert so hearing 'fantasia in F minor' was awesome, luckily it was used well. Such a beautiful piece.

This is a drama and was supposed to be a movie about celebrating alcohol and how the world would have been different without it, but the director's daughter tragically died 4 days into the filming so he decided to make it about drinking and celebrating life + what alcohol can/can't do.The acting was really good, by all 4 of the friends. If you like drama and/or enjoy drinking, check it out. It's one of those movies that'll make you feel all sorts of emotions in bits and pieces and will also make if you do some introspection. It's also an interesting take on the Danish drinking culture, apparently people are allowed to drink at work 30 years ago?As is the case with all drama movies, this may not be for everyone. But so many people seem to really enjoy it and relate to it. It's already won a ton of awards and has been nominated for several. It's likely going to be talked about prior to the Oscars, so you might wanna give it a shot before Apr 25th.

reviews.review_title: A truly different and fascinating concept
reviews.content: It's a pretty interesting movie, with an interesting concept (that I truly considered could be valid before googling it after finishing the movie lol), and it's overall beautifully shot, with great acting, cinematography and soundtrack.The camera is mainly hand held I would assume, so it gives you a fairly fluid effect throughout, and mainly on the drunk scenes I think it positively affects the experience of the movie itself overall.Mads Mikkelsen is just a phenomenal actor, and it shows here every freaking scene, he's great, all the four protagonists of sorts are really good in here, as is Maria Bonnevie as Martin's wife too. So, the cast is pretty solid overall.The story tho, I'm a bit conflicted, for most of it I loved the story, and I thought it had gotten the message it was trying to pass, however, after the movie is over, I don't really know.Cause, well, they drink, it sort of helps mainly Martin at first, but, of course he exceeds himself and losses it, as do his friends, they stop, but Tommy isn't able to, and that is clearly what kills him, Martin gets a text from his wife, saying she misses him too, implying Martin has a chance to get his family back... but then they are all drinking and partying like crazy again, in what I assume is still during the day of Tommy's funeral, so... what is the message here? Like, we see the characters go through hell cause of their bad choices, then we root for them, we want them to get better, their friend just died, and here they are getting wasted again? I just find it hard to understand the characters motivation at the end, and it feels a bit like wasted time when at the end of the story, you feel like the characters learned nothing.I had an amicable debate with a friend about the movie afterwards, and well, he strongly defended the story, and the finale for the most part, saying it was actually supposed to be a critic on Danish culture, and the fact that they drink like crazy. And well, fine, ok, I get that, I can see it, and I respect it and like most of the stuff they putted in here as a clear critic. However, still, imo what Martin does at the end, in a lot of ways sorts of denies most of the stuff we thought he had learned throughout the story. And as I said, it feels tough to relate to a character we feel should have learned a lot from the experience he just had, but apparently didn't.Still, I think the movie has a great cinematography, it's pretty well directed and has great performances all throughout, it's definitely worth watching, but the end sort of ruined what I thought would be one of my favorite movies of 2020.

Bored? Stuck? Middle-aged? Why not try the greatest elixir guaranteed to open up the mind, free up the tongue, and see the world in a cheerier light? Well you sir, and you madam are in luck, for this anti-inhibitor miracle which comes in a dazzling array of colours and tastes, is readily available and could well be right under your very noses. That's right, booze!Four cranky high school teachers, grinding the second gear of life with no foreseeable excitement ahead, decide to liven up their days with the magic of alcohol under a seemingly scientific experiment excuse.The theorem:
the human body's alcohol level is a tad low, and requires some topping up to run at optimum efficiency.The experiment:
the subjects drink steadily throughout the working day in an anti-sobriety test, and carefully monitor the results in a very clinical manner, using a computer!The result:
well, that would be telling, but chances are most astute viewers will connect the plot dots without much effort.The conclusion:
what sounds like a half-baked script for a slapdash comedy aimed at the immature set, turns out to be quite the serious and thought-provoking film. Also: Mads Mikkelsen stars, which is always welcome.Alcohol over indulgence is a major issue in dark Denmark, and as such this film will pierce many a Scandinavian home with a personal arrow. For those abroad "Another Round" will be less of a cautionary tale, and more of a buddy-buddy-buddy-buddy story of supposedly grown men wrestling with their maturity and various mid-life crises. It is not all about the drink, but why they drink. Using harried, jaded, aging teachers in charge of jubilant youth about to kickstart their glorious lives, is an intoxicating stroke of genius.Did I mention that Mads Mikkelson stars?
Excellent.hipCRANK

reviews.review_title: Vinterberg and Mads - a killer duo
reviews.content:
Another achievement from director Thomas Vinterberg, it's been an absolute delight discovering multi national films, this is coming from someone who for a long time got stuck with American movies.After seeing The Hunt from 2012 from the same director, I was automatically drawn to getting to know more of his work, fast forward to now and his most recent masterpiece "Druk" (Another Round - English title).
It tells a story of 4 high school teachers who seem to be experiencing what you could generically classify as a "middle life crisis" and decide to embark on an experiment based on a real life controversial theory, that the human being is born with a deficit of alcohol in their blood, so they decide to have a low level of alcohol ingested on a daily basis to test this out.First of all the movie is incredibly realistic, both the student and the teachers depiction as well as their relationships and personal lives are so naturally brought to the screen you almost feel you are actually seeing a real life story, and this I believe is one of the strongest aspects of the movie, of course this is accomplished by the amazing direction skills as well as the acting department, specially from Mads Mikklesen himself.You get drawn to the story and the characters, and strangely enough the movie isn't either a celebration or a censorship for alcohol consumption, given that Nordic countries including Denmark, have a very different relationship with drinking and culturally they are indeed associated with high consumption of alcohol, the movie brings out the awfulness and the harm that it can cause to someone's life, but at the same time, it also showcases that in certain aspects or circumstances it can also be an enabler, specially when the source of joy doesn't come from the consumption itself, but instead, the consumption serves as a celebratory method to showcase your happiness in the first place.It's a controversial topic, and this is what I like about this director, you probably won't get such honest themes being depicted on your regular Hollywood movie, and this guy isn't afraid to show you his approach on a topic regardless if it's a taboo one or a controversial theme. Fantastic movie, I hope it gets the recognition it deserves on the coming award season.

Druk is a terrific blend of light comedy, social drama and feel good movie. But Druk is more than that for me. Being a 40 year old teacher myself, I found myself recognizing a lot of the struggles the main characters are facing. The film made me laugh, made me feel, made me linger about my own life. It's a film that will stay with me and will be revisited in the near future. So I can feel those same emotions again. And that is what only great films can do. So a big thumbs up for Vinterbergs triumphant film.

Craig suggested this as a night in watch ... but we watched No Way Home instead. I think he'd have preferred this one. :)I liked this but was left wondering what I was supposed to think after it. Maybe that was the point.The experiment brought tragedy and really messed up their lives, and only Martin seems to gain any hope at the end of the film.Great performances but only an ok story.63/100.

In my honest view, this is Vinterberg's finest work since "The Hunt". With a splendid casting and a brilliant directing we got a natural film that intelligently communicates with the audience.I really enjoy watching the authentic danish side of Mikkelsen.

There is surely a singular word I can't quite conjure that captures the feeling of awkwardness that comes from seeing imminent disaster looming in personal circumstances. From the start I felt like a vicarious Cassandra watching 'Another round' - yet deeply uncomfortable as it is at points, this is a rather entrancing movie, more than I expected.I like Mads Mikkelsen, and think he's a fine actor, but I'm not on board with the sense of fandom that has come to surround his career. Despite the accolades this picture has garnered, the basic premise as described on any given website didn't strike me as a feature I'd enjoy - many movies have already been made about drinking, and none have particularly curried my favor. So I find myself ever more surprised that I've enjoyed this one.The varied elements of 'Another round' are familiar, and maybe a bit tired as tropes, but this is a case where the sum is greater than its parts. This is a movie about middle-aged men, teachers struggling in their personal and professional lives and seeking renewed vigor. Deciding to partake in a social experiment, they begin a steady course of alcohol consumption as a means to better themselves.Director Thomas Vinterberg pointedly captures every alcohol-soaked reverie and sullen downturn the picture takes, with a keen eye lets the viewer vividly feel every beat. The cast is more than up to the task, bringing Vinterberg and Tobias Lindholm's screenplay to life very believably. I'm particularly pleased, too, with the editing; the intermittent use of title cards to cheekily boost the narrative, or display text messages on a stark black background, is a fine film-making choice. The end result is - dare I say - intoxicating.The outcome of the film for each character isn't especially surprising, nor the ultimate theme that's laid bare by a student during final exams. Yet by the time this last leg of the movie rolls around, we're well on board with the story being told, and enraptured with the performances. The ending is pleasantly heartfelt, emotional without becoming overly sentimental, and a perfect capstone to a feature that works its way under your skin.I began watching with mixed expectations, and they were well exceeded. I need to correct myself, even - I think I can say this movie has made me a fan of Mads Mikkelsen in a way I wasn't before. I don't think I could argue with the decisions of awards judges if I wanted to: 'Another round' is an excellent film and deserves to be seen by a much wider audience.What a life, indeed.

reviews.review_title: I didn't know anything about this...
reviews.content: I mean I had no idea and of course I was a bit skeptical cause it looked a lil' boring cause at the beginning everyone seemed to be like on qualuds or downers lol, but after a while when we got to know the characters a lil and then a lil 'more a story started to develop and I got sucked in like a creepy black hole and then the ending came and I was like wow really cool! Really felt at the end that even though something bad did happen , in spite of this , it felt like a nice celebration of life and the vast possibilities. I hope I see more from the people involved in this film cause it really worked for me I mean I really think it was a very nice story and I highly recommend it.

I felt compelled to write a review as a longtime admirer of Mads Mikkelsen and Vinterberg as well as having strong opinions about alcohol. Vinterberg makes beautiful movies and Mads is compelling to watch, as always. The movie starts out so promising, we're drawn into the world of these characters who feel they're missing something in life and turn to alcohol as a solution. But as the movie progresses, the story doesn't. I was waiting for it to go somewhere and maybe show that one can find that relaxation and joy within themselves and not need alcohol. Instead it takes a predictable turn without further insight into the conflict within each character. To me it seems they attempted to make a movie about alcohol culture without any insight. Considering the amount of suffering and deaths alcohol causes, it ends up feeling hollow like the message is: "hey, alcohol can be bad so don't drink too much but look how fun it is to party!"
I have to say I expected a bit more. I think the idea is there but the story could use some more.. spice..

reviews.review_title: This movie stayed in my head for weeks after watching.
reviews.content: It's been a long time since I saw a real movie. This is a real movie. A really good movie. Mads Mikkelsen is awfully good. He is charismatic, good-looking and ruggedly convincing when he is sad/crying. When he cries in this film and in "The Hunt" it's so resoundingly powerful.All the guys have really good chemistry together. They seem to be having a g oodtime. They all work at the same school (it's kind of a high school mixed with a kindergarten) and they seem to have it good. However, it seemed really depressing at first. Then I thought: "how can you want to be a teacher it seems too hard", but later towards the end I can understand why you go through the tough times, because it seems like really worthwhile work. You can create really special relationships with the students if you are a good teacher and you can make a big difference.I haven't seen a lot of good movies lately so this one was nice. I've only seen old, outdated and boring junk. Movies like this are why movies are so popular. It is true to life and it makes you feel all sorts of emotions. Everything is so well done and feels so genuine. After a real movie, something has to stick in the head, and this one did for me. Just a really lovely and bittersweet film that you can't put down immediately after seeing it. You shouldn't feel empty after watching a movie. This fit like a charm.

If you enter the theatre with no preconceptions about this film, then, like me, you'll start off thinking you're watching a comedy. As the film progresses, you'll realise just how wrong this initial impression was.I believe the message of the film is actually nothing to do with alcohol. Rather, it is a testament to the virtue of living life whole heartedly and with full commitment, rather than letting oneself slip into lethargy and detachment.I wasn't fully convinced about the point of the film until the superb ending, which completely won me over. Highly recommended, unless you prefer pacier and flashier films, in which case you might find this too deliberate and slow moving.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant story of booze and people
reviews.content:
Great acting , great writing , great directing .
Love this film of loss, love , and alcohol .
Funny , sad , tragic , but that's life .What a life

I like the style, but the problem-solving process is still a little superficial. The theme of middle-aged crisis is not new. I want to present all kinds of life under different scenes through drunken experiment. The idea is very good, but it is very weak, which is related to the director's control and may not be able to control multi-line narration. Finally, the most impressive is uncle Mi's solo dance. I adored this film.Vinterberg absolutely nails it. The man just gets it. Humor, drama, emotion, complexity and those moments that make life so special yet also undeniably frustrating. The rollercoaster ride that brings us both the pure joys yet also the lowest of the lows. This film somehow encapsulates those feelings that makes our entire existence on this godforsaken planet so excruciatingly special. Here's the thing though, I absolutely noticed how Vinterberg uses some familiarity in the narrative progression to ease us into the film as there are definitely elements here that one could find sappy and cliched in any other film- but because Vinterberg refuses to go for coca-cola-sweetness and instead serves up a fine meal of refined tastes, you don't question it, you accept it, with a confident smile you say "of course, this makes absolute sense in the context of the film".The editing and cinematography are phenomenal. Let me be clear, if you don't think this film looks good, you don't know what you're talking about.
