reviews.review_title: A celebration of Binge drinking nothing more
reviews.content:
My Review- Another Round or "Druk" (translation Drinking or Boozing )
My Rating 4/10The 2021 Best International Feature Academy Award Winning film from Denmark.We got around to watching this film from Denmark and I didn't know what to expect and perhaps I got lost in Translation.I'm not a wowser those who enjoy a Social drink good luck to them but I found this movie very confronting and totally unenjoyable.Denmark has some of the highest rates of teenage drinking in the world; a World Health Organization report released earlier in 2020 found that Danish 15-year-olds consumed alcohol at nearly double the European average. Recent efforts to raise the minimum age for purchasing alcohol to 18 from 16 have met with resistance, in part because older adults recall their own youthful intoxications so fondly so you would think a film about 4 rather stupid men consuming huge amounts of alcohol in an experiment wouldn't serve Denmark or any other Nation well , it's certainly not a comedy like " The Hangover "2008 which I haven't seen out of choice.While the acting is excellent in "Another Round." and I've yet to see the other 4 nominated International Feature films which were "Quo Vadis, Aida?" (Bosnia and Herzegovina), The Man Who Sold His Skin Tunisia, Collective Romania, and Better Days Hong Kong I really disliked "Druk" and the translation is quite accurate it's all about Drinking snd Boozing and it leads nowhere expect and says nothing except to quote a line from the movie from Martin's Mads Mikkelson wife Anika (Maria Bonnevie) "I don't care how much you drink all Danes drink like madmen " and that's all this film is about
four high school teachers who consume alcohol on a daily basis in an "experiment " to see how it affects their social and professional lives.What did they expect would happen ?Of course they go crazy , their students and Principal have an intervention ,their marriages and children are traumatised one dies . (Sorry spoiler but I hope no one sees this film)
The reason being from the opening scenes of crazy teenagers drinking and misbehaving in a train to the last scenes of Mads Mickkelsen showing his acrobatic skills in a joyful salute to out of control alcohol abuse.The actor Mads Mikkelsen ends Thomas Vinterberg's film with a wild delight of a drunken dance. He was a professional dancer and can certainly move well but this movie had absolutely nothing to offer me at all and I can't recommend it at all.

reviews.review_title: (2020 list except) Vinterberg skillfully lampoons drinking culture
reviews.content: Another Round, or Druk in Danish, is a depressing-yet-comical exploration of the modern religion that is alcohol consumption.Being a veteran of the Dogme 95 movement, writer-director Thomas Vinterberg skillfully makes the film feel natural and, in accordance with the manifesto, almost never artificial (the movie looks to be shot in real locations with mostly natural lighting). Similarly convincing are Mads Mikkelsen and his co-stars, continually making me forget that these are actors and that there is a screen between us. Mikkelsen is emotionally convincing and has an absolutely glorious dance number near the end of the movie.As a Scandinavian, I can verify that it accurately depicts the drinking culture we have here. There have been complaints that the portrayal seems a bit exaggerated for the sake of a point, but I assure you; our high school graduates absolutely ride around on loud party trucks with champagne close at hand.
Interesting central plot. Bland and simple characters/developments. Simply over-rated.

reviews.review_title: Don't watch if you're already over 0.05% blood alcohol
reviews.content: Just watched another round for the second time. Another Another round if you like. It was so much better than the first watch. My theory is that my blood alcohol level was above the optimum 0.05% when I first watched it and thus I wasn't at my optimum self. This time I opened a beer as I first pressed play and topped up accordingly to reach around 0.05% from 30 minutes in to the end. Result? Utterly brillant. Thought provoking. A little sad. But ultimately joyous and made me cry at the end. Moral of the story? Don't have 3 pints before a film (only during)....

There are some films that were made ten years back that have proved to be timeless because of their sense of production and screenplay. Though this is a new film I can already imagine it ageing very well. The story unfolds in an innocuous way with characters you might feel very very sorry for. And then - you forget that sorrow and their joy becomes yours. Outstanding sets, loved watching with subtitles. I must take me to Sweden. GREAT ACTING.

reviews.review_title: Better than the Oscar best picture nominees.
reviews.content: This is one of the best pictures of 2020 and even better than all the nominees for Oscar best pocture category, leaving 'The Father' of course cause that film is very special to me. This film explores the Danish drinking culture and I've seen some reviews going on about how it's glorifying alcohol consumption. I beg to differ. If you'd watch the whole film properly, you wouldn't hold that opinion. This movie is much more than a comedy. It's quite deep and has been shot beautifully. The performances are amazing and Mads Mikkelsen has given the finest performance of his life in this film. His acting is so good and natural that you will feel like doing a character study. I give this movie an 8 and extra 1 for that beautiful ending scene. One of the more beautiful films I've ever watched.

Another Round is a protest film. The film protests against prohibitionism. Denmark has a culture of drinking. Traditionally Danes drink when they are celebrating, and they drink to break the ice. Having a beer with a working lunch would not have raised an eyebrow as little a decade or two ago. It isn't uncommon for highschoolers to drink heavily on weekends. A Swedish character in the film says, 'everyone in this country drinks too much.'But Danish drinking is on the decline. Today Danes buy half as much alcohol per person as they did twenty years ago (based on my own calculations from Denmark Statistics). In the last six years I have been at Copenhagen Business School, the university has banned drinking on campus except with special permission, and more or less eliminated Intro Week, a heavy drinking series of ice breaking events which is tradition at Danish universities.The film is about four high school teachers who only go through the motions work, and are unsatisfied with their home lives. When the main character Martin (Mads Mikkelsen) asks his wife if he has become boring, her evasive answer tells him all he needs to know. Early in the film one of the teachers quotes Norwegian psychiatrist Finn Skaaderud, that people are born with a bit too little alcohol in their blood. Martin sneaks some vodka into the school the next day, and his teaching goes much better than usual. The friends meet again, and decide to use themselves as test subjects for Skaaderud's theory.It isn't only the characters who are intrigued with the hypothesis that alcohol can improve our lives. Thomas Vinterberg, the director and co-screen writer, is completely on board. The film is a paean to how drinking can make us more fun and more interesting. It makes the teachers more creative and braver. It reduces students' anxiety. It reignites the characters' dying romantic relationships, and strengthens their bonds with friends.There is, of course, another side of alcohol, as the characters find out when they up their doses. Alcohol is associated with crimes of many sorts, from petty crime like vandalism to violent crimes like assault. Drunk driving makes roads less safe. We all know people whose lives have been destroyed by too much drinking. The economist and cultural critic Tyler Cowen has written that it is appalling that we drink such a dangerous substance in front of our children.Another Round does not ignore the negative consequences of alcoholism. Later in the film, alcohol causes some serious consequences for one of the characters. But for the most part alcohol does not create problems for the characters as much as solve them. Heavy drinking is like a coming of age ceremony. Not everyone who goes through it comes out unharmed, but those that do are changed for the better. The thesis of the film, in a word, is that alcohol is good for people, most of the time.The film is worth a view, if for nothing other than the provocative point it makes. It does not hurt that Mads Mikkelsen's performance is spectacular, as we have come to expect. So, do as the rest of the audience in the Danish movie screening I saw did, and watch the film with a beer in hand. Will drinking benefit your experience? Probably.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful. A Movie About True Friendship
reviews.content: Mads Mikkelsen is incredible in this movie. Another Round (Druk) is a movie about 4 friends, who are also teachers, that decide to use alcohol to fix their boring lives. With emotional elements, drama and tension, Another Round does not drag once. It is also superbly written, great dialogue, as well as great character changes and ways to sympathize. From the beginning, we already empathize with Mads Mikkelsen. This movie is beautiful, sad, and about friendship. Your friends will be there for you, and you will be there for them. Director Thomas Vinterberg did an amazing job with this movie. A must see.

Review By Kamal KA rather interesting concept that is executed brilliantly. It's probably quite a relatable issue aswell, particularly for those who rely on alcohol for some kind of release for their busy day-to-day lives.Mads' character is the one particularly focused on as he is the one who has the most to gain from the experiment, dealing with communication/social issues between his students and his family. So it's also quite a treat to see his character development throughout everything that happens.Overall, a rather enjoyable watch that will leave you feeling satisfied. And if you've ever wondered what it would be like to day drink regularly this movie will certainly make up your mind.

Another round had an interesting premise but it was not able to deliver as it had lots of stories but little time to deeply cover any one of them. It rushly accounted all it's stories thus seemed disconnected and purposeless.The idea of applying Skarderud theory could have been interesting and amusing but the movie failed to deliver cause it was not able to focus on any one of its stories and hastily addressed it's premises. And we don't even see the characters do crazy fun stuff when under the influence except the occasional dancing with a music montage playing in the back. Peter Griffin's drunken gang did more entertaining stuff than em.The 4 main characters didn't even seem like best friends at first but just colleagues since no time was spent to show their closeness.And referencing famous people and writing an essay about your drunken endeavors does not make your drinking less foolish. The study they pretended to be doing to justify their boozing came off as pretentious. Their drunkness also exploded at bullet speed as they rashly kept bumping up the alcohol level they ingest in just a couple of days. They were drinking like reckless teenagers not grown adults working on an experiment.The mindless heedlessness of the students in the beginning of the movie was also very annoying and it being justified by saying ' youth are generally stupid ' was plain stupid.Mads Mikkelsen could have also done better. He just sadly broods or dances around when drunk and no memorable performance was seen from him. His character also begging his cheating wife to return was galling to watch. We don't even know why his friend ended up killing himself cause the his plotline was rashly covered.The movie came off as a cursory and not a thorough discourse of alcohol , family relationships and self harm. It does not deserve the hype it's getting.

I don't even know where to start with. What was even the point of this movie? A bunch of grown ups decide to drink more to see how it affects their lives. Even a 12 year old knows that problem with alcohol is addiction and that could have drastic affects as days go by. It's all so predictable. And it's not even like they try to prove some point or that some thing has changed. Why would they leave their friend like that is a mystery or they are just plain stupid. Then Mads' wife comes back to him all of a sudden. It's like those cliched movies where the writers just do whatever they want with any character without any logic. I understand that it's more about how life is and the behavior of people when such things happen, but.. that's exactly what you expect, so I don't get the accolades. I am not sure if people of Denmark expect something else because of their drinking culture though. Nothing makes sense really, many boring moments through out, the only thing that stands apart is the acting, Mads and Thomas as always are amazing.I absolutely loved Vinterberg's previous movies I watched - Hunt and Celebration. In fact, the moment I came to know that this movie was from him, I decided to watch it but it has been utterly disappointing. I'm giving +1 for the last dance sequence from Mads, it was a joy to watch.

Danish/Swedish co-production from director Thomas Vinterberg starring Mads Mikkelsen best known to mainstream filmwatching audiences as characters such as James Bond villain Le Chiffre in Casino Royale (2006) as well as collaborating in a previous Vinterberg film with great success, The Hunt (2012).The premise is slightly exciting based on a factual idea from a Norweigan psychiatrist Finn Skårderud, that humans naturally have a blood-alcohol level lower than what it should be.Four Danish schoolteachers including history teacher Martin (Mikkelsen) test the idea to inject some zest into their moribund mid-life personal and professional lives.Martin in particular describes his circumstances his failing relationship with wife Anika and poor history teaching career that had so much spark and potential a few years before. The students and principal aren't particularly endeared to his teaching performance with end of school exams on the horizon for some.Initially the 'experiment' is positive and slightly comedic in that they find their mojos as such. Slightly drunk but not to excess and within control.However as the film progresses the blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is notched up bit by bit with tragic consequences. Vinterberg neither glamourises or demonizes alcohol culture and the director shows both sides of the coin cleverly using historic figures such as Winston Churchill and Hitler as examples of historic leaders who were either regular drinkers by their own admission and control yet heroes to many (Churchill) and tea totallers yet historic demons to many (Hitler). There is also a little montage of alcohol in modern day political life from Yeltsin and Clinton to Boris Johnson and Angela Merkel.The tragic consequences shown are the usual symptoms of alcoholism and include career difficulties, physical injuries from falls etc. Relationship issues and breakdowns.Excellent performances from the principal cast not only Mikkelsen in the comedic and tragedy scenes.The ending initially comes across as a bit corny for want of a better word but on reflection the celebratory scenes rather than Danish students and their teachers dancing around a harbour as if it is a musical could be a celebration by Martin or as in the title is he just starting the journey into 'Another Round' just as his life is turning a corner?Rightfully received awards recognition including winning Best International Feature Film at the Academy Awards in 2021.

reviews.review_title: A Masterclass In Acting And Filmmaking
reviews.content: Another Round is not just a contender for the best foreign film of the year but its also one of the best movies of this year. A very written story about alcohol culture in Denmark which leaves you with a lot of thoughts in your head once you watch it. Mads Mikkelsen is brilliant as always, he has been one of the most consistent and versatile actors of this generation and in Another Round he delivers a performance on par with his career best in "The Hunt".Many may feel this film encourages alcoholism but its anything but that. It shows how alcohol affects a person's life and his surroundings. Its like a feel good comedy until the final third act which is unpredictable and leaves a morbid taste to the viewer.

I watched three Mads Mikkelsen movies in a row recently... Chaos Walking, The Salvation, then Another Round, all of which I hadn't seen before, and each one an improvement as I went.Mads is of course brilliant in all of them, but Another Round really is such a great movie that is so well acted and delivered all round. The direction and script is superb, and that final celebration scene is one of the most amazing I've seen in a movie.Another Round had me laughing, crying, and engaged from start to finish. Quite possibly my favourite Mads performance yet, and he's one of the best actors around in my opinion.Recommended for everyone!

Did I watch the same movie as everyone else on here?!
This was seriously one of the slowest, most dull, boring, empty movies I've seen in a looong time. 4 old guys have a few drinks a day for a while, then they talk about it, then they go about their boring lives, while other boring characters around them go about their own boring lives and nothing really happens.Not a single likable character in the whole film. And sooo many characters that were plain frustrating in how trivial and dull and empty they were (Martin's Wife... I'd turn to alcoholism too if i had to spend my days with such a terribly dull person). Extra slow-scenes filled with trivial dialogue that leads nowhere. Dull classical music throughout that slows down the pacing even more and somehow (i guess) tries to make it all feel like some arty film. And the irritating shaky cam throughout.I bore myself giving any more thought to this film. 2 stars for Mads Mikkelsen - great actor, here too - but hardly can he alone carry on his shoulders such a disastrously boring film...

What a beautiful, beautiful ride.Another Round is an intoxicating (thanks Stephen Dalton), smile inducing and thoughtful dramedy simply about life. Thomas Vinterberg's film is touched with a known personal tragedy but the film is about embracing life and the fact that he was able to continue to (expertly) direct this film is an ode to him and his craft.The script is from Vinterberg and long time collaborator Tobias Lindholm has so many layers and allows each character to share their own experience. Obviously Mads Mikkelsen plays the main character, but a brilliant ensemble of Thomas Bo Larsen, Magnus Millang and Lars Ranthe all shine with their individual moments. Millang in particular makes me laugh a lot not just in his films but in interviews, a very Danish sense of humour which I share.The chemistry between the men is infectious and it is clear that the four are good mates in reality, I found myself laughing more in this film then I expected. I knew it would have funny moments but certain reviews make it out like it is a depressing drama which in my experience was not that case. Be ready for some serious laugh out loud moments.It also helped I had a decent audience, Australian audiences can sometimes be a little worse for wear but I had a great audience (we were all last minute cinema goers before our round 3 of corona virus induced lockdown).Mads Mikkelsen is amazing. We know this. He has been my favourite actor for almost ten years and he can do no wrong. He is heartbreaking, funny, pathetic at times and just contagiously mesmerising. Of course we have to mention the final scene which shows all of his hidden majesty. Like Shaun Parkes in Steve McQueen's 'Mangrove' (Another performance that will wrongfully not get recognised this year), Mikkelsen's face takes up half the screen and Vinterberg and brilliant DOP Sturla Brandth Grovlen allow him to do all the work by simply putting the camera to his noggin.Technically this is a sound film. The aforementioned cinematographer Grovlen is brilliantly loose with his camera and captures everything like a fly on the wall, there is some brilliant use of on screen text and photographic montage and the colour grade was incredibly luxurious.This film is something I believe we all needed (and still need) after what the world is going through at the minute. It is a celebration of friends, culture and life. Something that we should not take for granted.Mads Mikkelsen for Best Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role

reviews.review_title: not sure what this movie is trying to say
reviews.content:
I think the title says it all. I'm giving the 3 stars SOLELY because of Mikkelsen's dance scene.
starting with the very premise of the script, which is to investigate the influence of alcohol on social behavior.
I'm not going to get into how they "conduct research" without any kind of control groups, or even taking into account their individual physiology for alcohol consumption (maybe not all of them have the 0.05% tolerance). I simply cannot understand what was their point.What did they consider as an optimum behavior (that alcohol facilitated)? Mikkelsen gets drunk pretty fast in their first day of trial, but later leads an incredible class compared to his boring lectures. For him, optimum behaviour is not being boring. Almost similarly, but to a much lesser degree, Lars Ranthe's problem (Peter) 'sounded' more tangible. However, again, not enough is told about him to make us sympathize with him.What about for the other two? Does Magnus Milang's character (Nikolaj) tolerate his miserable family life better? reviews.review_title: One of the most engaging studies of the effects of alcohol on the human body ever put to film
reviews.content: "Another Round" (a.k.a. "Druk") is a comedy drama film directed and co-written by Thomas Vinterberg ("The Hunt"). Starring Mads Mikkelsen in the lead role, it is one of the most engaging studies of the effects of alcohol on the human body ever put to film.In Copenhagen, Denmark, high school teachers Martin (Mads Mikkelsen), Nikolaj (Magnus Millang), Tommy (Thomas Bo Larsen), and Peter (Lars Ranthe) are long time friends who each believe that their lives have become uninteresting over the years. At Nikolaj's 40th birthday party, the quartet decide to conduct an experiment where they consume alcohol at work to test a theory that a person with a BAC (Blood Alcohol Content) of 0.05% performs with a heightened level of creativity and confidence. As the days go by, each of the four friends discover that things are improving for them significantly and soon agree to take the experiment further by increasing their BAC limit to higher percentages.In pretty much every country where it's legal, drinking alcohol is widely considered to be a normal part of a fun night out where one is able to let loose every once and a while. Coming from Australia, one of the most well-known countries in the world to focus around drinking culture, I can personally attest to this as I myself have attended my fair share of parties where such an occurrence is the norm among young and old. As is usually the case with something this important, there are bound to be several films focusing around the consumption of alcohol that are meant to show how much the characters can handle before doing something they later regret. "Another Round" not only follows this formula to such a wonderful degree, but it also works brilliantly as a tragic commentary on middle age affecting one's acceptance in society.On the surface, this film may come across as a mere pastiche about group of friends getting drunk simply so they can function better at work. I think such an assessment is unfair because there is far more to this when examined more closely. Alcohol affects every person differently - some develop more confidence in their social abilities while others turn into a depressed wreck. One thing is for certain though, it changes people into someone they normally aren't when sober. This film cleverly uses each of its four main characters to show the various ways of how alcohol is both benefitting and worsening their lives. As a result of this, the film neither glorifies nor condemns its usage, instead depicting it almost as a tool that requires a particular set of skills to master.Each of these four men feel like that they are in a midlife slump with a nostalgic longing for the good old days. Take Martin for example, who is a history teacher whose students don't even respect him anymore due to how bland his teaching methods have become as a result of growing older. One student even stands up and leaves his class out of sheer boredom, not caring one bit if he gets into trouble. When Martin starts drinking before entering the classroom, he transforms into an entirely new person. Before you know it, he is engaging his class in jovial lectures on historical leaders and bringing out the best traits of his students. Like spinach to Popeye the sailor, alcohol eventually serves as a dependable means of acquiring the necessary strength for Martin to accomplish otherwise difficult tasks.But it isn't all good news for him. Eventually, Martin's overdependence on the liquid courage distances him from his family, putting a strain on his marriage. Martin's wife Anika finds it hard to comprehend that the man she married is now more concerned with looking good in front of his students than her. Despite assuring her that he is currently the best person he has ever been, Martin soon realises he has achieved this goal through selfish means. At this point, the film addresses Martin's deeply rooted insecurity - he is fearful that growing old has impeded his chances at success to fit in with the younger generation. These feelings of self-doubt are common among the middle-aged population, so it certainly isn't difficult to believe that many others out there must feel the same way as poor Martin.Director Thomas Vinterberg does a flawless job intertwining each of the four characters' stories with one another, bringing a solid consistency to the overall plot. Although Martin is clearly the main protagonist, his three friends are shown to have just as many interesting traits and quirks worth exploring as well. Due to the nature of their drinking experiment, the four often meet up to see where they are and how things are playing out for them. As previously mentioned, the alcohol affects each of them differently so it's fun to see the results of their lengthy investigation. In doing so, there's a nice balance between genuine drama and tongue-in-cheek comedy that makes a film like this seem so much more sincere than other alcohol-related features of this type.As Martin, Mads Mikkelsen gives one of the best performances of his career. This character could easily have been just another generic man facing a midlife crisis but Mikkelsen brings such a likeable, charming, and often humorous tone to the way he plays him that I eagerly anticipated everything he was about to do next. He never feels like a caricature of a typical drunken dad, instead he's a tragic individual who wants to improve his life as quickly as possible. The three other actors, Magnus Millang, Thomas Bo Larsen, and Lars Ranthe, were also great in their respective roles as Martin's friends. They too have their own obstacles they need to overcome but their differing worldviews prevent this from being a smooth journey.In this day and age where films tend to sensationalise alcohol consumption, it feels like a breath of fresh air to finally watch one that actually provides a more neutral perspective on everything. Though it is true that alcohol has been the cause of many issues in people's lives, it has also led to the creation of several amazing things as well. Renowned author Ernest Hemingway claimed to have written some of his best work while under the influence, but in stark contrast, millions of lives are lost worldwide each year due to excessive drunkenness. The key here is moderation, like the use of an important musical instrument in the composition of a symphony. To quote the immortal words of Homer Simpson: "To alcohol! The cause of - and solution to - all of life's problems!"I rate it a solid 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Love without sex. Is it possible? Yes, and sweet it is.

Martin (Mads Mikkelsen)Another Round is a Danish drama rightfully awarded the "International Feature" Oscar while the director, Thomas Vinterberg, was nominated for director. Although mid-life crisis has been amply treated in films around the world (think Wild Hogs and Sideways for starters), this one goes deeper than most exploring the chaos of four teachers experimenting with alcohol to spice up their lives.The acting is superb-Mikkelsen should have been nominated. The analysis of the crisis is better than any lecture.Using Norwegian psychologist Finn Skarderund's work about the need for human blood alcohol to maintain a 0.5% level, Martin tries it and finds he's a better teacher when he's drunk. His three buddies follow, with degrees of success that impel them to reach higher levels. Only the most dimwitted audience wouldn't see the disruption to personal and professional lives that will ensue.However, the film keeps it even between the obvious domination of drinking and the needs it reflects, especially for domestic lives that are immediately affected by the excess. Actually, nothing dramatic erupts during the first two thirds of the film, just a slow deterioration of each one's ability to control his environment. Family life for Martin is almost from the beginning vulnerable to his change, and not for the better.Nor does Another Round take it easy in the end by showing them mature and sober. In fact, it's hard to decide, even after a tragedy touches them, that they will lead sober lives after the graduation of their students. The fact that these middle-aged teachers need to revive their lives is ample proof that they need intervention, but alcohol is not the candidate."The world is never as you expect." Martin.

reviews.review_title: Mikkelsen is great in a middling film
reviews.content: Mads Mikkelsen is such an underrated actor, and 'Another Round' provided the perfect role to play to his strengths. Even though the film is a little bit of an ensemble cast, he is undoubtedly the star of the film. He has the most screen time and his acting is light-years beyond the rest of the cast. We know him as the very quiet and under-stated man he plays in most of his films, and that is what he starts the movie as, but then when he is required to become more out-going as the film goes along is when we see his acting chops come to the front.The movie does give a reasonably balanced opinion on the subject matter. It starts out only really showing the positives, which I found to be quite a dangerous notion. However towards the end it makes a point of showing the negatives that would ultimately come from such a thing. I'm not entirely sure what this film is going to inspire people to do however. reviews.review_title: Watching four idiots trying to find meaning in life through alcohol
reviews.content: We are watching four grown men believing the solution to their apathy and boring outlook of life is to be found in a regular, daily consumption of alcohol.I found it mildly entertaining early on while they experimented with staying at a low alcohol level - I was interested in how that would work out over time.However, at some point they decided to increase the intake well into drunkenness. This was obviously not going to work out and was just plain silly - turning all four into uninteresting idiots for me.The only interesting aspect left of the movie after that point was to see whether they learned something from their "experiment" and maybe some message to the audience regarding alcohol consumption. Not so! The movie ends ***spoler alert ** with the wife wanting to get back to the husband (why did she want to get back to the drunkard??), and instead of appreciating his good fortune and taking a final farewell to alcohol the movie ends with the main character getting drunk yet again and dancing around drunkenly and happy.There is no message here. No deeper meaning. Just four miserable idiots looking for an easy answer to improve their lives. They don't find it through drinking, one of their friends drinks himself to death, their lives only got worse and STILL they end up drinking and partying at the end.If anything, this movie is a tribute to alcohol and might even send a message that alcohol is a good thing.I give it 2 stars instead of 1 because I love Mikkelsens acting.

reviews.review_title: Mad Mikkelsen runs the wild show!
reviews.content: Once upon a time, a Norwegian psychiatrist posed a theory that people are born with the blood alcohol content 0.05% too low. Four 40 year old highschool teachers decide to test that theory - in the name of science- by maintaining a state of perpetual tipsiness while they are working and going about their lives. Needless to say, it turned out into one hell of a movie!The experiment was a smashing success. Our heroes enjoy every minute of this study by stashing bottles everywhere, finally connecting with their students and galavanting around the town without a care in the world. The film itself becomes brighter and more colorful as we watch Mads and his palls get into all sorts of situations. Before watching, I knew that a film about alcohol consumption is meant to have a number of moral lessons and before long, those lessons are presented in a most heartbreaking way.Thomas Vinterberg and Mads Mikkelsen deliver yet another thought provoking and moving film that will stay with me for a long time. Each character hopes that the experiment will help with their particular life problem and while it does help to an extent, the price ends up being too high. The way it progresses from innocent joy and warmth to somber reality is reflected in both the cinematography and terrific acting.Whether you consume alcohol or not, this is a film that you need to watch. Another Round masterfully manages to have an absolute blast while teaching an important lesson without ever being "in your face" about it's messages. Alcohol is a big part of society regardless of country, social strata or age and the film shows that it is personal responsibility to determine how much of it is truly enough. What deserves a special mention is how this story is wrapped up in one of most enjoyable endings of 2020.movies.shmovies on Instagram for more great movies

reviews.review_title: A point I'd like to make, having read some negative critic reviews
reviews.content:
I agree with another user here who says this isn't a comedy. Perhaps 'dram-com' is the most apt category available for the convenience of the nextflix algorithm, but this really isn't that-neither is it a tragedy only, or a drama. It is irreverent.
Perhaps it's important that I preface by saying I'm a 25 y.o. American, which might give you a rough idea of my cinematic purview. I've seen few foreign films which have stuck with me, among them Babette's Feast and, to a lesser degree, Oslo, August 31st. This is more alike the latter (albeit not so morbidly depressing). To avoid spoilers and still make a point I'd like to make, I think it's noble of the director to steer clear of chauvinism, despite that the more negative professional reviews such as that from The Guardian insist to focus on what they deem a 'pro-alcohol' message. If the director has any predilection he's trying to share, it's that life is worth enjoying, even if that means taking the forbidden sip or two. There's no patronizing here-just an honest character study, the four-man cast cornering four primary and different character traits, at least one of which nearly all of us will share.
To get back to the comedy thing, it is a joyful and funny movie (albeit equally dark and poignant). But it doesn't demand laughter or tears. The subtle grace with which Druk progresses unconcernedly has that distinctive European feel, and it is a refreshing respite from the formulaic stories we are used to being told. (The underlying story itself here is simple, predictable and cliche, but that doesn't matter-life itself is as much, yet as a richly lived day, though predictable in its broad turns, shimmers with many uncontrived moments of triumph and novelty, so does this movie progress-generally as expected, yet in a strangely inverted, paradoxically novel way.)
Mads is brilliant. He's the reason I was willing to buy this, frankly, the option of renting being unavailable.

They are in their forties, they are either missing the life before children or regretting never having them, they don't pay suffient attention to their romantic relationships, they are uinspiring teachers at a high school where all the kids would rather stare at their screens... And their resort to escape this reality is alcohol.Their situation surely might be relatable, but it's also incredibly cliche. The dramatic curve is also entirely predictable.They drink alcohol and suddenly turn into sublime teachers who are saluted by cheering teenagers. They pay attention to their partners. Everything is swell.The drink more alcohol, and things turn even better, but the movie hints that we might be approaching hybris.They drink even more alcohol and their situation turn misrable. Who would have been able to predict that?The movie suffers from this predictability throughout. To give another example: In a scene, one of the characters (I can't remember the name, apart from Mads Mikkelsens excellent performance, the characters are rather - yes - ordinary) exclaims: "I wish I had children, no one will remember me as i grow old." In the very next scene, the character meets a distressed high school student and they develop a memorable relationship. What a ride!I could keep on listing several similiar examples, but that would spoil the movie.I guess the movie is daring in that it celebrates alcohol and alcohol culture in a Danish society that frown upon teenagers' (hefty) alcohol consumption. If you are one to get provoked by a celebration of drugs and the proposition that drugs (such as alcohol) might be a helpful aid in living a more inspired life, then this movie might shock you and/or give you a few new ideas.Since that thought does not provoke me in any particular way, I was left unfrazzled.It's a weird take on a feel good movie. There's alot of warmth but not a whole lot of depth.If you feel like watching a feel good comedy with a novel concept about a stereotypical group of male friends that realise that alcoholism in fact does not fix their existential problems, knock yourself out. If you want to be provoked, touched, surprised, inspired - then I don't think this is it.

reviews.review_title: A feel good film that hits hard when it needs to
reviews.content:
POSITIVES:1) The four leads are all incredible. Mads obviously carries the film as the lead, Martin, but the other actors were really great too
2) The emotional moments of the film really worked for me, for example I really cared about how Martin and Anika's relationship was going to turn out
3) I was surprised by how much the film actually stuck to the theme of the drinking being a psychological experiment, there are frequent call backs to the leads writing their research down
4) Seeing Martin finally dance at the end was euphoric; the whole film people are trying to get him to dance and he says no, but then at the end he finally lets loose and I found it so fantastic
5) The film is very heartfelt in a very realistic way, the relationship with Tommy and Specs was so down to earth which made it hit homeNEGATIVES:1) I definitely felt the film was too long, there was about 20 minutes that felt like they were bagging the run time
2) The switching of the gears with the experiment felt quite rushed to me. It really doesn't take long for the four of them to agree to do the experiment, then once they do it really doesn't take long for the four of them to agree to up the stakes multiple times

reviews.review_title: Alcohol is a trickster of a pal
reviews.content: An emotionally astute movie about drinking culture and middle-aged angst. There's a sort of poetic quality to Thomas Vinterberg's direction, but Mads Mikkelsen incredible performance carries the film, a talent so present even at his most withdrawn, battered and saddened. I thought the message of the movie was muddled at first... Is alcohol good or bad? However, said message became clear to me when the movie ends and the frame freezes: "To alcohol! The cause of -and solution to- all of life's problems."

Kind of the way Mads' portrayal of Lecter did in Hannibal; he was even better than Sir Hopkins in that role. Miscarriage of good taste that it was cancelled, clearly a victim of America's dumb-it-down culture that has zero patience for anything cerebral, but I digress. For many moons I've said that Mads is our finest living actor...though, admittedly, I sometimes vacillate between him, Mahershala Ali and Sam Rockwell. For just as many moons I've been laughed at and sarcastically, sometimes sincerely asked "who?" Well now I feel vindicated, just like a drunk in a midnight choir, caught between flying and drowning. Especial kudos to Vinterberg, for whom this film I'm sure provided a modicum of release from operatic grief. The flick, as a whole, is far more efficacious than any AA meeting and much braver in its shares. A luminous intoxicant that somehow manages to be immediately sobering in its very own visceral way. And who wouldn't want to go on a pub crawl with good old Mads!?

reviews.review_title: "I don't know how I ended up like this."
reviews.content: Who's to say being born with a blood alcohol level of less than .05 is too low? Wouldn't the normal situation be that one is born with no alcohol in one's blood? Unless of course, the mother is an alcoholic giving birth; that would make some sense. The outlandish concept intrigued me enough to look up the name of the scientist mentioned in the story. Finn Skårderud is a real person, a Norwegian psychiatrist and psychotherapist who's also an internationally acknowledged expert on eating disorders. The theory on which the film is based is not only untested, it's not even a real theory. It comes from a misinterpreted preface written by Skårderud to a book first published in 1880, 'on the psychological effects of wine'.With that said, the story focuses on four adult friends who decide to take the matter of achieving an .05 blood alcohol level seriously, to see what it does for their personal relationships and professional creativity. When early results appear promising, the group makes the fatal mistake of assuming that if a little bit is good, then more must be better. This results in the characters falling down drunk and making a mess of their lives to the point of harming themselves, and in the case of soccer coach Tommy (Thomas Bo Larsen), falling off a boat and drowning during an alcoholic stupor. (Whether his dog was recovered safely was never resolved).There's also a questionable scene in which one of the men named Peter (Lars Ranthe) suggests that one of his students take a shot or two prior to taking an oral exam to calm his nerves. It works for that student for the sake of the story, but I have to wonder how bad a message that might send to an aspiring undergrad. Seems to me there's enough alcoholism in the general population without encouraging it in the name of education.With some serio-comic moments, the film does explore the often horrific side effects of uncontrolled drinking and how that can ruin relationships and a promising future. If I were in a flippant mood I'd say to keep a drink handy while watching, but the tone of the picture is just a bit too serious to take lightly. A montage of real life politicians under the influence is shown at one point, suggesting that some of their world influencing decisions might have been poured straight out of a bottle.

reviews.review_title: Drinking like only the Danish can
reviews.content: Dark, joyful, challenging and wondrously complex, this is a character study of the double-edged sword that alcohol can be in the lives of those seeking revival, release or escape or in the case of four Danish schoolteachers, coping with midlife crisis and a desire to feel free again. These colleagues and friends initially view the concept as a curiosity, but as soon as one of them (Mads Mikkelsen in an explosive performance) actually experiments with the idea, his enthusiasm becomes infectious. From that point on, their curiosity evolves into an obsession and their lives and those around them are affected accordingly.I dare say this film conveys its complicated message and portrayal of human weakness with such realism that it's almost like a documentary. It's highly unlikely that an American film on the same subject would have been this powerful or this real. Do you still smell the alcohol?This is hardly a brand new topic for a film to cover, but this one does it so well, that it makes the whole subject matter seem devastatingly fresh and incredibly real. The best compliment that I can pay is that the characters are true to life in their behavior, in their gradual collapse of discipline and in the impact they have on their families and students. You cannot look away. You can only wonder how it will all end. The film subtly shifts between anguish and exuberance with stunning skill. This is first-rate filmmaking. Highly recommended whether this is your drink or not.

After finding The Hunt (2012-also reviewed) to be superb,I been very interested in catching the latest project by the makers. Discovering that the film was being screened at my local Odeon for just one night,I decided to go up to the bar and buy a round.View on the film:The lone figure sitting at the table stone cold sober, Mads Mikkelsen gives an excellent performance as Martin, who sits silently as Mikkelsen casts across his face the absolute drained out state of Martin's life, whilst Thomas Bo Larsen brings out a great bohemian warmth to Tommy's rough-edge friendship with Martin.Dedicating the film to his daughter Ida after she died just four days into filming, (Ida was originally going to co-star in the movie) co-writer/(with Tobias Lindholm ) directing auteur Thomas Vinterberg & Victoria (2015-also reviewed) cinematographer Sturla Brandth Grovlen pour a pint out straight from Vinterberg's Dogme 95 roots, with harsh natural lighting caught in sparse close-ups on the descending drunken state of the friends.Bringing an underlying bitter sweet after taste to the mood, Vinterberg unveils cracks of brightness through the brittle naturalistic appearance, with wonderfully staged singing and dancing sequences, (a recurring motif in Vinterberg's work) which whilst appearing to be sunny, also subtly stage the impression in the final shot,of Martin following Tommy off the deep end at sea.Encouraged by his daughter to adapt a play he had written into a script, the screenplay by Vinterberg (and Tobias Lindholm) sadly never fully departs from the stage-bound roots, via the limited locations and number of characters who get involved in this drunken spiral.Sipping into the drinking experiment of his friends, the writers gradually have Martin become engulfed in an uncontrollable urge to delve deeper into the drinking culture his friends are fully submerged in,as Martin orders another round.

'Another Round' is one of those films where my lasting impression is one tainted by a sense of what could have been. Let me state clearly for the record, the film is by no means a failure, with a lot to like: As you would expect, Mads Mikkelsen is sublime (particular praise must be given for his work in the film's first half, with such subtle physical touches used to great effect. These evolve into an impressive and wildly different physical display later on), the central premise is innovative yet involving, the supporting cast solid, the score oh so memorable and there are some real moments of humour and novelty, as well as some poignant, important questions raised.But. But, but, but. A Best International Feature Oscar. An acclaimed director. One of the world's best leading actors. I really expected this to hit harder and to lead to a more incisive finale. 'The Hunt' still sticks in my mind months after viewing it, and whilst it's a notably different affair, I can't help but notice how Vinterberg really crystallises the lasting tension, pain and emotion perfectly in its closing scenes, whilst Another Round's ending feels diffuse by comparison.Sebastian was clearly a vehicle for the film's central through line, the Kierkegaardian notion that 'you must accept yourself as fallible in order to love others and life', however the scene in which this is delivered felt like somewhat of a cop out. If this was truly a powerfully observable, lived reality for the characters, we wouldn't have needed this signpost moment. It's clear that Vinterberg is aiming for a structure which illustrates the idea 'everything is the same, but everything is different', with the return to the restaurant, the implied reunion of Martin and Anika, and the bookend scenes involving the students' unbridled, drunken celebrations, however instead of striking that note it feels rather as if the central characters, and indeed the film, haven't truly confronted their problematic realities and made a definitive choice, statement or realisation. It feels rather as if Tommy's death just facilitates a tail off into a return to life as before, which is obviously not the intended feel.I really, really wanted to feel differently about this, to revel in Mikkelsen's fantastic final moments, and to emphatically feel that dual sense of pathos and joy of acceptance which I know Vinterberg was aiming to invoke. But 'The Hunt' it is not. The promise does not fully materialise, and, to my mind at least, we don't emerge into a sobering reality but rather are left with a hazy, hungover like state in which we have some muddled sense of what should have been, but are left wondering exactly where things went awry.

reviews.review_title: Liked it but did not love it.
reviews.content: It is a good film that deserves its accolades. The direction is competent and the movie is constructed around an interesting and creative premise: that the human body is made to tolerate a higher level of alcohol than naturally present.Yet the movie kinda falls short in the third act. It takes you to high places and then to really low points, but then it does not know how to resolve it. The plot lays out a number of thread and ideas, but it does not conclude them satisfyingly. It botches the resolution or abandons most of them to end in a soft happy end that is somewhat disappointing. When you learn that it is based on a short the director made years ago, it makes sense. It does feel like they streched a neat tidy idea without an end in sight. You could shave a half hour of the movie and not lose anything.The first half is great though. From the beginning, you discover that it is a movie about Martin's middle-life crisis disguised as a social drama on the effects of alcohol. It is cleverly written, the performances are excellent, and you rapidly engage in the social dynamics of this merry group of friends. The first half documents the rise, and obviously, you're expecting the fall. But, it never really comes, and that is where the movie gets frustrating. There are glimpses for instance that Martin had something darker in him from the start and that this alcoholic binge is just a façade that will be his downfall. But, there a never real adverse effects to the characters actions and we never get there. Drinking in the day time has mostly positive effects.Even when they increase the dosage they don't really suffer the consequences. The sequence where they get poop faced is not nearly as transgressive or humiliating enough. One guy gets yelled at by his ever-nagging wife, and Martin wakes up on his neighbour's lawn. It needed a scene of a real low point like one them wakes up at the hospital or they forget to turn off the stove and burn the house down. It needed to go full Trailer Park Boys Jim Lahey.In the second half, the story that was about a man's middle-life crisis turns into high-school drama. It is not necessarily bad, but it comes out of nowhere and is not nearly as riveting. The characters face low-points that ultimately are rather painlessly resolved and feels hollow. There is something of a disconnect with the beginning of the movie that felt more loaded and subversive. The character that was the least developed and had the less to lose abruptly dies without a real reason leading to it. Everyone rekindles with his or her wives and children; it is a missed opportunity for genuine catharsis.I feel that it would have benefited of following a more generic structure where Martin's tendencies lead him to self-destruct. That's what the narrative needed, a man who immolates himself through an addiction. I liked it, but I wanted to love it.

reviews.review_title: More "skul" for better skills at school? An experimental review of "Another Round"...
reviews.content: I enjoyed Thomas Vintenberg's "Another Round".Why? Maybe because I'm an introverted guy drowining his introverted sorrow in pints of beer, wine, vodka... but not whisky. Or maybe because I'm a teacher and I can relate to being confronted to a class whose deadly silence is a severe blow to my pride. Or maybe because I'm kind of a simp when it comes to women, whether the first or the second. Or maybe because I already used alcohol to fuel some positive energy... and that it worked. Anyway I was the perfect candidate to enjoy it and I enjoyed it so much that I'm willing to do an experiment (I did one for "Festen", check the review).Since the film is about four men and teachers (with their own issues and marital troubles): history teacher Martin (Mads Mikkelsen), P. E. teacher Tommy (Thomas Bo Larsen), philo Nikolaj (Magnus Millang) and Music Peter (Lars Ranthe) decide to prove a theory that implies a man's alcool level at 0,5g maintains or improves his social skills and creativity, that state between drunkenness and soberness. I'm willing to do a similar test and advance in that review after several drinks. This is not an endorsement of drinking, no more or less than the film but let's do it for fun. See you later.Well, here we are, two small beers, I guess I'm there at 0,5g. How does that affect my writing I don't know. I just want to take an opportunity to say that I could really relate to the scenes that depicted every single stage of inebriation by Vintenberg. From the way, you start stumbling and looking for the right word, or just talking loudly and smiling to the way you start loosen up. There's a real portrayal of alcohol effect that takes me back to the first time I drunk, drank, whatever, when my cousin asked me to approach a girl and I was shy, it took one bottle of Malibu pineapple and the magic operated, placebo, maybe. Anyway, I could relate to the character of Mark, he's lost his appeal with his wife and girls and one glass of wine is enough to bring back the worst and anaesthetize it. Alcohol becomes the remedy to the very thoughts it catalyses, strange but true.Having said that, I dream to be a filmmaker and one of the film I dreamed of making since 12 years involve a long sequence of guys drinking and dancing and a climactic catastrophe dancing that is almost like Madds at the end. And so for the record, I want to make it clear, if I ever make such a film, please don't accuse me to make a rip-off. I swear I had it in mind years and years before. Let's hope this will serve a purpose.Where was I? Just had two and half glasses of wine. I guess I'm in a stage where my mind floats in total lucidity, and I already feel silly about the former paragraph... how about just making a film without caring about any accusation of plagiarism. What Vintenberg did was more than offer a platform of expression to average guys who want to be heard in a world where it's about the pleas of youngsters or women, I suspected Vintenberg was a fan of "The Deeer Hunter" when I saw "The Hunt": you know, male-bonding etc. , the drunk scenes especially when they want to literally go the distance is just like the bar scene pushed to eleven... men behaving like a children, he wife wants a fresh fish, how about fishing it... I like the way Vintenberg use the process of handheld camera to exteriorize the drunken effect like Harvey Keitel's "Rubber Sandwich" scene in "Mean Streets".The directing, rightfully Oscar-nominated is both subjective and objective, it shows the state of mind, shows the way they look at their own entourage, whether kids laughing at their jokes or women telling them to calm down and it shows a certain reality about couples, exams, needs for existence and that found a perfect loophole with alcohol. Does the film advocate the drinking? Well given the most extreme scenario and the fact that a man wets his own bed and Marcus ends up laying on the ground, I doubt so... but what Vintenberg does is acknowledge that there's a reason for existence (remember what Homer Simpson said?) and he doesn't back up in the controversial scene where a teacher advices a student to drink before answering, it can help... I'll be back...Now, I guess I got to the limit, my head is heavier and I'm tired. Maybe that' what consumption is about, there's an aftershock, something to bite you back that is called reality... Vintenberg draws the line between reality as it seems and the the virtual universe we fabricate to improve or please ourselves.... I was perplex about the ending, why cut the focus from the experience and leave us with the aftermath of the first booze orgy... maybe Vintenberg settles a personal record with destiny (check the trivia) and out of honesty decided to show that alcohol is a life-and-death issue whether physical or "social" death. Still the same...However the ending that seems to embrace the energy boost of alcohol within the students and their intergenerational communion with teachers suggests a social cement, a rite of passage, as wicked as it is, it exists and that one should handle it with responsibility. It's interesting that if Marcus could get his wife to notice him with alcohol, her comeback is due to one moment where he chose to be sober... and maybe there's a certain sternness, a strength in that sate that can take you further in life... and watching the quality of the directing, I was sure there was no alcohol involved during the filming.Think about it before calling the film an ode to alcohol? Off to bed now...

I can enjoy realism, fantasy, fable and even fairytale, but each of those genres implies a contract with the audience who agree to suspend judgement in exchange for having the film deliver in ways that it otherwise couldn't. Another Round veers between those genres and I found myself alternately suffering lack of imagination in the name of verisimilitude and lack of plausibility in the name of a jimmy-rigged premise. Many crucial developments happen off camera, things the viewer "doesn't need to see," but I never discerned what made many of the things we do to see necessary to see (except perhaps that they were simply easier to stage and film). Chekhov said "One must never place a loaded rifle on the stage if it isn't going to go off. It's wrong to make promises you don't mean to keep." Watching the first hour of this film you know "this can't end well," and if that promise isn't completely broken, it's delivered in bad faith - a disaster that serves as a pretense for a celebration.I'm not a reviewer who needs a film to agree with me about the issues, I don't need to like any of the characters, I don't need to see the wicked punished, etc. But I don't like feeling manipulated, and I tend not to like story telling that uses people (here Tommy particularly, but also Anika) as props.

reviews.review_title: An entertaining, funny, and sometimes emotional film that should (hopefully) appeal to a wide audience
reviews.content: I can't remember too many other high profile foreign films from 2020 off the top of my head, but Another Round surely has to be a contender for at least the Best Foreign Film Oscar. Nominations for the screenplay and Mads Mikkelsen's performance would also be well-deserved.Another Round takes an entertaining and unbiased look at the effects of alcohol: the good, the bad, and the messy, as well as the variety of ways different people can react to similar quantities of the world's favourite legal drug. It tackles this without feeling preachy as well, which was appreciated. It's not as harrowing as other films that deal with more illegal substances and their effects, but there are a few genuinely emotional moments that hit pretty hard in the story's second half.The more serious moments are balanced well with a good amount of comedy, as the film is pretty funny at times. The wide range of emotions and tones help highlight just how well-written and balanced the screenplay is, and how skilled its lead actors are (especially, as mentioned before, Mads Mikkelsen, who steals the show here and honestly can do no wrong as an actor, as far as I'm concerned).It starts a little slow, but picks up nicely 20 minutes or so in, and feels extremely well-paced from there until the end. Perhaps a couple of events within the narrative happen slightly too fast, and the film's visuals - while good - don't make quite the same impression as the writing or acting, barring a few striking images in the film's final third.Overall, I really liked this one, and I'm giving it one of those 4/5 ratings that's actually very close to a 4.5/5. I think we need more straightforward, unpretentious, quite accessible foreign films like this (and something like last year's Parasite) to increase the popularity of world cinema, and help convince non-believers that not every film in a language other than English is obscure or "weird" or overly artsy.I mean, the more arthouse stuff can be engaging in its own way, but hopefully you know what I mean- movies like this one could get people more invested in films made beyond their borders, and in the overall scheme of things, that can't be anything but good for film industries worldwide.

In no way, I'm asserting my adverse opinion that the film is bad. Matter of fact, It's pretty darn good. But there are certain things that require pressing consideration!Whereas the story proceeds to unveil whatever damage caused by immoderate liquor consumption; it also ratifies the yearlong tradition in Denmark adjacent to the same matter. In all fairness; for an outlander like me, it is clearly hard to comprehend. Anyway, I get the feeling that somewhere in its transitions the underlying value of the key message slowly faded away.Although it sheds light on multiple crucial perspectives such as life, family, friendship; yet it all appears to be incomplete for some odd reason. On the other hand, there are certain sequences volubly brandishing an absolute brilliance and there's no denying its infallible quality of being subtle and evocative; all at once.Needless to say, other than its trivial shortcomings in the narrative; elsewhere, this has been quite a show worth beholding! Mainly apropos of the striking Cinematography; which quite frankly has exceeded all my expectations. And so did the poignant Score in the back.Finally coming down to the heart & soul of this whole endeavor i.e. The Performances. Long story short, the entire cast did an amazing job! It isn't uncommon for middle-aged men to turn to drinking to drown their sorrows, but, in Danish Director Thomas Vinterberg's ANOTHER ROUND the sad sacks conduct an 'experiment' to use drinking to give their lives a spark. Inspired by psychiatrist Finn Skarderud's controversial theory that humans should have a 0.05% alcohol level for peak performance, Vinterberg and co-writer Tobias Lindholm concocted this wry tale of four teachers stuck in personal and career ruts. Our main protagonist is Martin (Mads Mikkelsen) a history teacher who along with three friends at the school decide to take up Skarderud's challenge and conduct a formal experiment testing the theory by drinking all day while teaching class.The experiment begins positively enough, with the quartet finding a new gear. They seem happier, their job performance improves. But, soon, 0.05% isn't enough and marriages and relationships are roiled, beds are soiled and their jobs are endangered. As a morality tale, ANOTHER ROUND has some rather murky messaging. The seriousness of alcoholism in Denmark is only lightly touched upon. The original title - DRUK - can roughly be translated as "boozing" which is more spot on than the American title which makes it sound like a Hallmark cable movie. There is also some awkward plotting that blunts the dramatic flow. What makes the movie work is Mikkelsen and the cast. There is a genuine camaraderie with the four without falling into forced sentimentality. Maria Bonnevie playing Martin's wife, Anika, brings a genuine sincerity to her role that plays off nicely with Mikkelsen's mood swings.A bittersweet graduation scene carries an emotional resonance that has built throughout. Martin is said to have been a free-form jazz dancer in his youth, but the character refuses to dance in the movie even when his friends are prancing about drunkenly. Mikkelsen (who himself had a dance background) finally lets go in a cathartic boogie that frees Martin's spirit - and that of the viewer. It isn't a dance of unbounded joy, but of deep, well earned cleansing. It calls for Another Round - but, in moderation. Of course. Skol.

The alcohol is really just a catalyst to explore the lives of our main characters, allowing for a greater examination of them and their relationships.The plot is so engaging and well done. Perfect movie with Perfect writing and an absolutely amazing humor

reviews.content: Overall I enjoyed this a lot, although that's maybe because I didn't go to watch it intending to pick up any/many deep philosophical points of interest about one of my favorite things, which is having a drink.
