Another Round is directed by Thomas Vinterberg. The danish production won an oscar as the best international movie in 2021.Especially noticeable is the plot, the movie is about four teacher's, which aren't satisfied from there way of teaching and there whole life. Therefore they try to accomplish a theory, that every human being is born with per mille deficit of 0.5.All the different characters try to hold 0.5 per mille till 20 o'clock, bit through the whole experiment the whole situation escalates and end up in an alcohol frenzy.It is a very unique story and the movie is also starring Mads Mikkelsen and Thomas Bo Larsen, but also the other danish actors fulfill perfect acting. From my point of view music and camera work are not striking, the music and the camera work are very good, but there isn't any special way of the camera work and the music doesn't brings memorability. The movie is very controversial and tough to watch, cause of the enormous consume of alcohol. Sometimes it's unpleasant to see people drinking at 7am, before they interact with kids and teenagers.But Another Round is definitely the best danish film I saw so far and especially the plot is amazing. Deserved Oscar!

The message of this movie may be depressing but it is very accurate.The film is different by exposing the subject of the consequences of alcohol consumption, it manages to give its message very clearly, not only exposes what can happen to you but also how it affects your family and all the people around you. It is a harsh criticism of the normalized excess consumption of alcohol and how it affects society, not only in adults but also in young people, it also refers to the fact that alcohol is only an escape from reality and who does not want to accept reality will do everything possible to avoid it without realizing it. It is very well acted, the script is wonderful, and it even makes you reflect on why we like to consume alcohol so often. It is definitely worth a look, it has a very well deserved Oscar.

reviews.review_title: I get what you are saying, but how you say it is not absorbing enough.
reviews.content: Clear message and realistic portrayal of men in midlife. I really wanted to tell my dad how important he is to family and hug him after the movie. However, there is nothing strong to attract audience. Very bland storytelling and bland directing. In 'The Hunt, Vinterberg's former work with Mikkelsen, the story might seem mild and ordinary from the outside, the development and performance are so strong and swirling that it captivated and even engulfed me. I expected the same level of experience, but it is never there in 'Another Round'.

This film has an original and surprisingly simple premise, and it manages to both succeed in delivering that premise brilliantly, as well as add interesting features regarding the film form. Alcoholism is the main theme here, which elicits an interesting question to mind: What is the film's overall message and tone going to be? Is it going to promote a positive attitude towards drinking, focusing on the joys one an experience when getting drunk with friends? Or, is it going to illustrate the negative side effects of alcoholism? The answer? Both. And despite the balance and the necessary gravity of the theme that is explored here, the film maintains a very relaxed, fun, and lighthearted character. And it does all of this is a concise manner, which is reflected in the film's runtime (just under two hours). To top it all off, for me, the most beautiful thing about this film is that I know I can recommend it to practically everyone. That is how lighthearted and balanced this film is. It is not a film for admirers of a specific genre or anything. It is just a solid, fun, and entertaining film for everyone (except kids maybe).

There's a sad story behind the making of this film. Inspired by director Thomas Vinterberg's daughter Ida, who was also due to star until she passed away just as filming began. He'd be forgiven in shelving the whole idea, but instead tweaked it and dedicated it to her. I really want to love this. Martin (Mads Mikkelsen) is a teacher, a bored one. As are his fellow teachers. It goes a bit beyond boredom for Martin though, he's called out by his students and their parents for not being engaged enough. He's in crisis, "lacking joy", until one of his colleagues shares a theory about unlocking the minds full potential... with alcohol. To be honest I'm going to call it here. It's not alcohol that helps Martin, it's his friends. They're solid. They care. Sure they're daft, but there's real compassion amongst them. It also helps that they collectively decide to test the alcohol theory. The theory being that the body is slightly alcohol deficient and that by topping it up a little and maintaining it, you'll be happier, more confident, productive, maybe even enlightened. What could possibly go wrong? Mikkelsen is very easy to watch. They all are really, but he's the focus and he holds it brilliantly. Martin blazes the path as the experiment becomes more... ambitious. I think there's a lot of Martin's out there. It's not really a story about alcohol, but of being lost. Lives loosing their sense of purpose. Denmark apparently has a drinking culture, especially amongst the youth. Surely no more than England, but who knows. I don't and it's not important, but the school kids respond to the more flamboyant teaching styles. It's uplifting stuff. An infectious energy permeates the screen. Especially when the needle drops on Cissy Strut in a gorgeous Scandinavian apartment and the dancing begins. Martin has a darkness in him though. He knows his limits, but with the others somewhat carelessly pushing on in the name of science. He finds the line blurring. They all do. It's raw and honest, with some very difficult themes, but Vinterberg navigates them all well. I'm not sure it's a film I can really love, but I do like it, a lot.

reviews.review_title: Obvious, predictable and boring. Good cast.
reviews.content: Totally obvious and predictable movie that takes two hours to tell you that alcohol makes you more fun, more creative, more daring, that it can even save your marriage, but beware...it's a drug, so take it in moderation. And naturally it shows that it is the wrong solution to the wrong problem and that it serves to disguise other real problems.Four middle-aged men feel that they have lost the spark of youth and believe that they can recover it by maintaining an adequate dose of alcohol. Sounds stupid? Well obviously it is and they are. And they forget Kierkeegard's quote that youth is a dream, they forget that euphoria is not the natural state of man.The film is an absolutely obvious and superficial analysis of what the crisis of the 40s is. Its sense of comedy is to show obvious scenes that everyone knows and expects, to play the hackneyed.Both the euphoria of the first half of the film and the catastrophe of the second half move in the territory of what has already been seen many times. This time it is intended to justify itself by presenting a supposedly subversive message... but not so much. It is what we see in so many independent films.The most surprising thing at a purely plot level, in addition to the tricky premise of 0.5% alcohol, is how 4 adults can think that someone is going to read their report on how 4 drunk adults behave.And it does not fill the 2 hours. The characters are uninteresting, although the performances are brilliant. All the supposed value is the analysis of the situation, and this is so simplistic and obvious that it does not hold our interest.
As a teetotaller (by choice), I felt I had to crack open a bottle of Heineken 0.0% while watching this very interesting study-within-a-study with its hilarious situations as well as tragic moments.
A compelling and thought-provoking film about alcohol culture, inertia, loss, beginnings and endings and the life in between. Also...Mads Mikkelsen...the man can do no wrong.

I have a very hard time watching danish movies being danish myself. I usually can't take the characters seriously and the way they express themselves in are typically extremely awkward, stiff and sometimes borderlines embarrassing. From that you can probably guess that a good danish movie to me is typical a dime in a dozen. Looking at my rating for the movie you will know that this is one of them. I absolutely loved this film. Most of all It's a fun time for everyone of the appropriate age, while still reaching deeper depths in its themes like life and alcoholism.The concept of your keeping a constant blood alcohol level of 0.5 precent with the benefits of having more confidence or being more open to meeting new people is something we all could need, and would make everyday tasks and life more fun. That said most of us know that being intoxicated at all times isn't the best idea, even if the benefits might seem better than the cons at first glance. It's so simplistic, in a good way, that it almost comes as a surprise to me having never seen a movie tackle alcohol in this manner.The writers, the cinematography and the actors all did an amazing job on this movie, which truly brought it to life. It has some much energy and the actors all have such great chemistry. The cinematography is beautiful and as the movie progresses you see the environment and lighting reflect Martin's, Mads Mikkelsen's, mental state evolve and dissolve.With an amazing cast, great music and a good sense of direction and plot, this is easily recommendable to a lot of people, and a movie that will be remembered in the danish movie industry for many years. It's monumental for us Danes that Thomas Vinterberg won the Oscar for best international feature film, and congrats to him for making an amazing movie.9/10.

This movie just might be the perfect example of how life of an ordinary person who drinks occasionally looks like. Starts out boring as their day-to-day life it speeds up when alcohol becomes their frequent companion day in day out up to the point of no return mark and that's usually when someone gets hurt or when it gets ugly (or both). Alcohol pretends to be your friend to make you feel good and confident, it loosens you up and shows your inner fears, thoughts, your hidden demons and not everyone is strong enough to cope with being on the loose all the time. In general Another round speaks loudly of all those things and would be relevant for everyone who knows drinking problems not by hearsay (which is like half of earth's population), to all of the others it would be just another movie with its moral shouting loudly since the beginning and its general idea spoiled in its poster already. That's why I intentionally named this review after D.W. Griffith's infamous 1909 short feature because of how similar they both are in concept. Overall this is a good movie with some nice soundtrack, fine dramatic performances (although a bit too strained for me), some proper thoughts to think about and a smooth aftertaste.

reviews.review_title: Fun to watch but still shallow waters
reviews.content: Let me get this straight: it's a great movie with great music and awesome acting! But - yes, there is a but - it feels like the moviemakers had a great chance to educate about alcoholism and just missed it. When things got real bad, they backed off and said: oh - that's it now, let's make it all good again. I get that the movie isn't about alcoholism but rather about the individual characters and their lives, but their lives are destroyed in a way by their experiment that no quick talk could fix what broke. And that just doesn't come out. Either way: it's still fun to watch and the close-ups of Mikkelsen are great, I laughed a lot and the quick turns in mood are well done. Still worth a watch!

How sad that too many people need synthetic stimulants to lift themselves up. Alcohol is the most dangerous choice by bored & boring people without creativity in dealing with life's stresses because it jeopardises or threatens so many others with violence or threats of violence & self-degradation, especially if one gets behind the wheel of a car or walks into a family with any instability whatsoever. This movie sanctifies drinking with a silly theory. Reprehensible for trying to dignify such irresponsible behavior. A 2-hour commercial for becoming a drunkard. I'm sorry I can't give it a negative rating.If you must sink this low to overcome stress, off yourself quickly in a way that won't take others down with you. Better? Get some therapy & learn out how to live meaningfully.Funny? Not in the slightest.

Very original movies. Usually movies are outlined about characters who try to get sober this one turns it around - Thomas Vinterberg's newest entry to his filmography is actually about "sober" people who want to get drunk to find a sense in life.... it started as an experiment but has a fundamental impact on the character's lives, emotions and developments.
The film is funny and tragic. Its an interesting mix as I wouldn't call it a light drama with comedic highlights like a typical dramedy, it is rather a tragedy with some funny or lets say soft elements. Its really a very down to earth film about normal people and normal fates. Very natural.

reviews.review_title: Mikkelsen shines in this cathartic tragicomedy!
reviews.content: The nailed-on favourite and today, the winner of the Best Foreign Film Oscar-Another Round is a transcendental journey of an introverted school teacher going through a midlife crisis.He joins three other middle-aged friends to embark on a depraved social experiment to see if daily alcohol intake can curb their inhibitions and make them more sociable and confident.While the downsides of alcoholism is well covered, I think the core message that Director Vinterbeg wanted to convey is that one should get high on life to get that extra spring in your step every day.Mads Mikkelsen's gripping performance as the fidgety, timid teacher is a big stretch from the suave Bond Villain characters we are used to from him. But is in this space that he excels, and I can't comprehend how he did not get a Best Actor nomination for this.Another Round is a delightful tragicomedy. Cathartic stuff.
Quite simply the best new film I've seen in ages. Mads Mikkeksen is fantastic, possibly his best performance.

This was...cheerful? And I liked that?Yeah, yeah I did. This must be the most optimistic film about alcoholism I've ever seen, because it's honest about it. It showcases the soaring highs just as much, and just as effectively as the crushing lows, and although it's not a position I've ever been in, it is one I could potentially have been.I remember when I first came to university and tried alcohol in a social setting, and it was like I'd suddenly unlocked a cheat code. I could talk to girls, I could say all that stupid stuff that I thought would make people laugh but never had the confidence to say before, and most of all, I felt happy.It's not like I wasn't before, but I wasn't exactly the most outgoing person, and that was something I badly wanted to be by the time I went to university. Knowing that, you can probably see how I could have all too easily gotten out of hand like the characters in this film do, but thankfully I managed to control myself just before I started drinking alone.I'm sure when parties and clubs can happen again, I'll be getting royally drunk, but I'm glad that I know my limits and when the appropriate times to drink are.All this stupid storytiming is to say that this film is relatable as hell, because man does it nail that feeling of not having a care in the world when you're just that perfect amount of drunk, and it probably nails how easy it is to slip into addiction as well.I'll say that the ending may have been a bit too cheerful considering what happens in the scene prior, and that some more interesting shot composition certainly wouldn't have hurt, but the performances are all brilliant, the direction from Thomas Vinterberg is amazing, the characters are likable, and for how much of a tonal disaster this easily could have been, it pulls it off so well.So if anything I said just now resonates with you, please watch this, cause sometimes, being honest doesn't mean you have to be miserable about it.

reviews.review_title: A great subject spoiled by a subpar production
reviews.content:
Photography, editing, scene design and the overall direction aren't good. Half an hour should have been cut.
The actors do their jobs but the characters/storylines aren't convincing: the screenplay feels just ok (I don't speak Danish so I can judge only based on the unofficial subtitles).
The subject-story deserves instead my praise: a remake might be a good idea.The initial Kierkegaard's quote should set the standpoint for the viewer (something which many revieweres here don't seem to have gotten).
The authentic ways of life all of us lost by becoming adults can be brought back by drinking alcohol. But is this an acceptable solution to deal with socio-economic and juridical pressures, cultural taboos, personal and interpersonal issues?
What do we really accomplish by drinking? The film's answer - as per my interpretation - is quite good: general, complex, non-preachy, open-ended and uncompromisingly tragic.

Until I understood that in the end nothing matters, the world keeps turning and the decisions you make will always be affected by the mood with which you face every day, you are the only one who can make a change and alcohol though give you force, it will not always be there.

The premise of the film is interesting. Teachers in a high school decide to live with 0.5 grams in their blood (at the beginning, then some increase the dose). This seems to bring benefits: Mads Mikkelsen, who is depressed (problem with his wife, problem with his job as a history teacher), is reinvigorated and regains his appetite for teaching. It also has positive effects on three of his colleagues.Then the doses increase, first a gram for Mads Mikkelsen. His colleagues too. Of course things have to stop, because the educational community realizes it (and it is frowned upon), but one of the three continues and ends up dying from it (suicide or accident, the film is not explicit, but it does not matter). By the way, curiosity, the only character who dies is the one who is single, who has no wife, and just a dog. The female characters are poorly developed and rather caricatural (the housewife with her three small children, the adulterous woman).The film thus goes from a documentary phase (the young people go on drinking courses and get drunk to the point of vomiting), to comedy drama and then drama.Mads Mikkelsen is very good. Nice performance.The film ends on the sequence of the beginning where the young graduates are going to get drunk to vomit. The professors celebrating with them, confirming somehow their theory that an individual who has permanently 0.5 grams in the blood is the optimum state.Is this a subversive movie?

reviews.review_title: A little alcohol makes you smarter, but it is addictive
reviews.content:
This film has got the Oscar for best International film, and therefore should be on your must see list
A Norwegian philosopher Skarderud has said that
" Human beings are born with alcohol level that is 0.05% too low". Does it mean can they can drink up to make up this deficiency and get smarter ? (Incidently this view has been contested)
So celebrated director Thomas Vinterberg makes an engaging movie on this subject.Four middle aged high school teachers of Sweden find their job mundane and boring. They decide to drink alcohol in moderation as an experiment to bring zing in their lives not realizing the consequences in store. They also prepare a day to day report on the effects of their drinking.Director has created a film which is entertaining and throws up some issues like midlife crisis, excessive drinking, school kids drinking etc against the backdrop of a Denmark school. The teachers led by Martin ( Mads Mikkelson) do find increased energy in their work and the happy students also experience this change in their teachers. However alcohol is addictive as they soon find out and their drunken demeanor puts their professional and private life in a downward spiral. Martin's marriage is in jeopardy and nearing divorce. All four manage to save their sanity and give up the experiment. The last scene with Mads dancing and enjoying with his colleagues and school kids is a highlight.An enjoyable film which is funny and touching in many places.

Personally I found myself asking me a lot of questions. Why do we drink? Do we drink to celebrate, or to avoid our problems? Do we expect to be a better version of ourselves? And if that's the case, why we choose to drink up our problems instead of facing ourselves and going to therapy?Yes, Vinterberg questions the drinking culture in his country, Denmark, but I think is something a bit universal. The drinking culture is also strongly present in Mexico. I find more interesting the portrait that Vinterbeg does between young people and middle age: why the young ones seem to be happy drinking, while the old ones seem to use the alcohol as a cope mechanism? I think that as we grow up, our problems do too. And frequently, we failed to face does difficulties. We feel anguish and a constant fear of failing not only ourselves, but the others around us -like the family. Somehow, every year that pass by our responsabilities and problems get bigger. And we failed to fulfill our longings, our mental and physical needs. The hole increases every year, and we try to cover it with alcohol.

reviews.review_title: A daring Danish warning disguised as a feel-good romp.
reviews.content: I wish people would stop declaring Thomas Vinterberg's latest movie as a promotion of alcohol. Dig deeper people, this fantastic film is much more of a warning to casual drinkers about just how slippery the slippery slope into acoholism really is. And just like how our four primary protagonists joke at the thought of themselves being alcoholics, we too can be caught up in the cloud of denial that these characters ultimately become shrouded in.Whilst at his own birthday celebration, Magnus Millang's psychology teacher, Nikolaj, casually slips into conversation with his three teaching collegues about a study done which proposed that humans naturally have lower-than-desired alcohol blood levels. The group seem uninterested, sip their wine and swiftly move onto a new topic. Mads Mikkelsen's character however, History teacher Martin, opens up to the group about his internal struggles- which he identifies are linked to his lack of motivation to teach when compared to his younger days.Soon enough, the group find themselves undertaking a research project which involves drinking the equivalent of 1-2 glasses of wine before a school day and subsequently recording the effects, which begin positive. We see where this is going, yet, I remained glued to the big screen as I was fascinated about the excuses that the teachers would conjure in order to raise the amount of alcohol they would consume.I'm convinced that this film will speak to many drinkers, casual or heavy, reminding them how fragile they are. They walk the line of alcoholism everytime they drink. And after the struggle of a year that many have faced, that line may be finer for some more than others. Screen this movie everywhere you can- it contains a needed message whilst being delightfully wrapped up in a sweet, feel-good container which is fulled to the brim with dark humor.No, it doesn't compare to Mads' 2013 project with the same director, The Hunt, but it does offer a two-in-one. What a beautifully made blast-of-a-movie that carries a hidden lesson we could all learn.

reviews.review_title: While most hollywood movies these days are terrible this danish movie deliveres

reviews.review_title: I love this movie - one of the best of the year!
reviews.content: It has been a long time since we have been treated to a movie like Another Round. It is set in Denmark and English is not its natural language, so if you cannot get on board with subtitles, I would not bother with this movie (and shame on you for not trying it in its natural language).Some reviewers claim this movie glorifies alcoholism and I do not know how to retort them other than to say that it is a ridiculous assertion and that this movie actually does the opposite. The "pro-alcoholism" critique of Another Round reminds me of when Joker (2019) came out and people said it glamorized people wanting to live the Joker's violent lifestyle. No one who actually watched Joker would want to live that man's life, and no one who watches Another Round is going to come away wanting to become an alcoholic.Another Round is about a group of teachers going through a series of mid-life crises who turn to alcohol to spice up their lives, at least at first. What makes Another Round great is simply the main cast and the fact that they all fit together well. The actors balance together a mix of drama, comedy, and tender moments, and it feels like Another Round is really all three of those elements together at once. It feels like real life, to that extent. We find humor in the drama of our daily lives, and vice versa.Mads Mikkelsen was born to play this role. I also appreciated that the movie did not follow the standardized, modern path that so many movies take nowadays of simply devolving downward into an "everybody suffers" ending. This movie could have gone that way where everybody goes overboard on alcohol and everyone loses everything that matters to them, but that is not what happens. Instead, we are treated to a very different type of ending, which I would simply suggest you watch to appreciate.

An Academy Award winner for Feature International Film was more than justified for Thomas Vinterberg's latest production starring Mads Mikkelsen - a Danish comedy-drama that delves into family, friendships and most importantly, alcohol.Four high school teachers consume alcohol on a daily basis to see how it affects their social and professional lives.The film has small pockets of brilliance in its overall dark and pragmatic script. The struggles to meet family matters and maintain civil friendships is encountered by all of the on-screen protagonists. Alcohol is used as a device to trigger these problems and see the good and bad its effects can have in everyday life. Significantly, the 'drinking' experiment takes place among 4 teachers, working of course in a place of drive and prosperity where children should be educated on the bad rather than the good of alcohol, however, Vinterberg ensures that the teaching flaws are explicitly presented in order to overrule any suggestions of academic gain.High quality performances are reflected even through subtitles and the articulation of the writing is interpreted even more clearly, the cast are evidently cohesive and understand their roles of assignment to make the film seem real for both comedic and dramatic affect. Music plays a key role in negotiating a somber and melancholic tone to switch so quickly into a party atmosphere as the spectacle moves from darkness to light.For a movie originally titled 'Druk' in its native country, translating to 'binge-drinking' it is certainly a watch to take the edge off - masterful.

reviews.review_title: Entertaining, thoughtful and reflective across the board
reviews.content: I suppose, it's my turn to deliver some insights, while I listen to "What a life" this movie shows with beautiful thematic uniformity throughout it.As a Dane, movie lover and whiskey aficionado myself, obviously it was very much about time that I finally visited the cinema to watch the movie. Better late than never, though, and thus am I glad, I got to watch it on the big screen in time.The movie perfectly balances the risk of alcohol glorification with the equally great risk of a lifted finger on this subject. At no point during the move did I feel either scolded nor encouraged to drink. Simply put, the movie merely presents the theme in a neutral manner, leaving it up to the viewers to make up their own mind about it. The latter being one of many reasons for the +15 rating in Denmark. It is a film for adults, plain and simple, so no further elaboration is needed on this note.Continuing, this of course means that there is no direct message of the film. The message is based on each and every viewer, who in turn is based on their own culture and relation to the inherent subject.Needless to say, but nonetheless necessary to bring up in this case, is the extremely incredible performance by all actors in the movie, including minor and micro characters.Obviously, Mads Mikkelsen (and "obviously" doesn't do this guy much justice here) is yet again able to stun and completely paralyze his audience with another luxuriously captivating performance, and... (Ohhh! Almost gave away the best part there. You will have to see the movie for yourself).Structurally, I occasionally got Tarantino vibes, though not as crazy and farfetched in a fictional realm as is often the case with his movies. "Druk" has a unique ability to stay grounded in such a comparison, keeping the pace of the film slow, steady and blurred, reflecting both the euphoria of being drunk and the different stages of alcoholism. (You will know what I mean when you see it).Frankly, the only flaw of the movie might be the missing (or hidden, or at least not easy to find) second plot point. I wasn't able to notice it, which resulted in a bit stretched sequence from about 70% of the movie until 85% through. Even if the previous parts of the movie did an excellent job until this point, in that exact range of its timeline not a lot of new information is introduced, and the movie therefore loses its pace and entertainment a little, which really is a shame, because it absolutely delivers on all other counts.All in all, if we take the heavy, dark and a bit clichéd theme and the structural stretch aside, the movie's Oscar is certainly still justified, because all the other film technical elements are in their right place, while daring to escape the "box" a little as well, keeping the movie original, fresh and conceptually interesting. So, to sum up: All the criteria for an Oscar winner are fulfilled here.

Four teachers decide to consume alcohol daily, in a controlled way, to put a theory to the test.To begin with, Another Round is not a film that celebrates alcoholism or the culture of excess. In some ways I consider this film to be one of the best since a long long time, because of the way it keeps the storyline attractive and exciting from start to finish.At its core, Another Round is an internal battle, ranging from existential doubts to nirvana, through issues such as depression, marital problems and the worst about human behavior.It's provocative, daring, corrosive and delightfully fun. It's a coming-of-age in reverse, a Benjamin Button, if you can say that.Mads Mikkelsen is superb, an actor who has shown his talent over the years, however, I do not feel that he has surpassed the role that for me is his best: The Hunt, also by Thomas Vinterberg.

reviews.review_title: AnotherRound is the answer to the question - Did anything good happen in 2020?
reviews.content: AnotherRound is the answer to the question - Did anything good happen in 2020?The quote at the beginning - 'What is youth? A dream. What is love? The dream's content.' - is the key to understand the film. We hope to live life to its fullest. And when we can't, we succumb to cheap options like drinking alcohol.The interaction between the actors and the director is terrific. The cinematography is outstanding. The slightly wobbly camera work is indicative of the high calibre of craft demonstrated. Mads Mikkelsen's performance ranks among his finest. He, along with his friends, attempts to fix his life with alcohol. Which works initially but can't be controlled. Up until the final moments where his entire life is in a shambles, when he gets the message - that hope shines. Only then he can dance. The last sequence leaves an indelible impact.The director Thomas Vinterberg lost out on the Oscar to the maker of Nomadland. Wow!

There is raw humanity all across this movie and it's really about passion and finding the way to reignite yourself long after life has become droll.The way the four pals in this story do that is completely dangerous and selfish but the film avoids turning into a morality tale and doesn't for a moment preach ideals to its audience. This is where it diverts from what an American studio handling the same material would've done.As for that ending dance scene, it's totally out of left field but also a complete delight. Now I need a vodka!

For me, it's always good to watch movies in other languages beyond American, so that is a plus!You can see that Thomas Vinterberg thought very well about the argument and selected the perfect cast to perform it. The characters were amazingly well-designed, and I guess it should be ordinary if anyone from their middle age can be related to some feelings and situations from the movie.It's definitely a drama but with a touch of intelligent comedy. There are some parts in which you can have a good laugh.Considering that some teenagers can watch this movie, I have just one (not so positive) note to make. There is one part where it seems that if you drink alcohol, you'll get successful. Probably that part wasn't necessary.But overall, I loved the movie. I was attached from the beginning till the end. I found it very interesting and catchy.

Thomas Vinterberg's Druk is about alcoholism; its attractiveness and destructiveness. Four middle aged friends who all work together; three of them teachers, and one a coach, decide to experiment with alcohol in their professional life as a means of increasing productivity in what they all perceive to be a boring life in some way or another. And from this point on, each decision made in this movie plays out exactly as you would imagine... but then that's what it is about. To me, the sober viewer, it is as clear as day, the implications and the effects the next round is bound to have... but not to the men who are already involved. It's almost as if a sense of safety and precaution is what you sacrifice first, and it was shown with much excellence on screen.Major credit to lead actor Mads Mikkelsen who channeled life through the screen. His evolving personality in this movie was portrayed so convincingly with passion and flow, and for that, he deserves every bit of praise. To anyone reading this, do check it out too when you have the chance. You won't regret it.

I will say this, let me say this, what I'm going to say is, on that one now, Mads Mikkelsen is most certainly a star. He can dance, he can act like Hannibal Lecter, he can bleed out of his eyes, and he can even be in video games.Druk is not quite the warning of alcohol abuse and dependency that Days of Wine and Roses was. It meanders through various tones and moods, begging the question: "What is Danish for 'melodramedy'?" Also, there must be a word in Danish for schadenfreude. Too much fun can be swell, but of course the high-school teachers will take their buzz-worthy experiment of maintaining 0.05% BAC too far, going from quarter-cocked to half-cocked and ultimately totally corked.The movie only suffers from an inability to suspend disbelief. It is hard to believe four teachers would engage seriously in such an experiment, risking their jobs and family lives. There is no finger-wagging or tsk-tsking. We must decide for ourselves whether we should drink more or less, resulting in a simple moral ambiguity instead of some stern moral lesson.Drinking booze can be fun, sometimes it can be dangerous, sometimes it creates a feedback loop of anxiety and depression. Is it possible to understand joy without sadness? Is it possible to be a responsible drinker, or should everything be done in moderation, including moderation?

reviews.review_title: A film that tells about more than four alcoholised men
reviews.content: Director Thomas Vinterberg cannot be praised enough for this film. After four days of shooting, his daughter Ida was killed in a car accident. After a week of mourning, the Dane was back on the set. The idea for the film was also inspired by his daughter. It tells how four middle-aged schoolteachers go through their midlife crisis based on a theory of the Norwegian psychiatrist Finn Skarderud, who says that a blood alcohol level of 0.05 makes people go through life more relaxed and free.Each of the four main characters gets their own storyline and lets us share in their suffering in life. Once the actually optimistic psychology teacher Nikolaj, played by Magnus Milland, who has to deal with bed-wetting children at home. Then the hapless choir director Peter (Lars Ranthe), who sees himself as an expiry model and cannot find love. Sports teacher Tommy (Thomas Bo Larsen), a coach who is actually loving towards his kids but lacks any motivation. And finally Mads Mikkelsen's character Martin. He accepts being a bore and goes through life virtually invisible, which has an impact on his marriage to Anika (Maria Bonnevie). The plot is told almost exclusively from Martin's perspective. Mikkelsen thereby appropriates pretty much all the facets a person can have. At first he is desperate, then through regular alcohol consumption he suddenly becomes lively and cheerful, before his emotional world is a constant up and down at the end. Mikkelsen disappears into his role and plays this character with a great deal of subtlety and sometimes impulsiveness. Not only Mikkelsen is fantastic, his three co-protagonists also act at a high level. This is especially noticeable in the scenes in which the four of them discuss their project, explore new spheres and go out together. In the individual moments, Mikkelsen stands out because Martin takes up the most screentime.Another Round is a funny film for the most part, although the dramatic moments predominate, especially towards the end. Only then do you really become aware of its seriousness and it takes you with it. Actually, many elements correspond to a classic tragicomedy. Vinterberg manages to lay out the film in such a way that this is not always obvious and you stick to one genre in every scene. It may be mainly about the (worrying) drinking culture among adults and young people in Denmark, but Another Round is also an appeal to life in general. Yes, alcohol can awaken undiscovered free spirits in people, but equally it can literally destroy relationships and lives. Vinterberg covers all these aspects brilliantly. Most of the film runs without any musical accompaniment. But when it does, the classical music adapts to the action. The same goes for the camera work and shots: When the characters are in crisis, the film drags. When they're on the edge, it thrills with outstanding pacing. Yes, Another Round may be tedious in places, but this "weakness" is made up for by the explosive finale at the latest, which may be the best of the entire year.

reviews.review_title: The hypothesis that alcohol improves your life
reviews.content: The film sets out to illustrate the impact on human behaviour alcohol has in our lives, good and bad, under the hypothesis that maintaining a low level of alcohol in our bloodstream actually improves how we feel and behave positively. Whilst this may be true, the challenge is in the maintenance. Alcohol can lift you out of middle age depression, mediocrity and boredom, by stimulating creative thinking and feeling. However, with it, comes addiction, destruction and annihilation. Each character suffers in a different way because control is unmanageable. This is not an anti-alcohol film but a study in the realistic virtue of alcohol treating depression.

There are few really good and joyful sequences in this otherwise slow burner of a film but it is the climax that you leave with in the end.The central character played Mads Mikkelsen is left 'open-minded-ended' in the end and it leads you to believe a variety of emotions on his behalf.My rating: 9/10 *********

reviews.review_title: Favorite movie from 2020 and long awaited
reviews.content: I was waiting for this movie to come out for so long. And finally I watched it today. I am obsessed with Scandinavian, Nordic cinematography, tv shows and films. We have ten more days till the end of month, but I think that not a single movie which will come out can't beat this one. This film has very original and realistic story, and mad group of actors. But number one is Mads Mikkelsen, oh my god, what a man, he is perfect in every role, the most charismatic actor from the last decade. He is the star of every movie he is in and stole every second. He takes everything to the next level. I would give him every award in the world, so I hope it goes well for him in the upcoming awards season. Also, the soundtrack is superb. Especially the main theme song "What A Life" which in combination with final scene makes a little perfection of the universe.

The closest translation from the Danish title would probably be "binge drinking". And with that in mind it's a movie that questions the Danish drinking culture in general, as a quote in the movie goes: "What is it with this country and drinking?"But addressing alcohol culture is not the only theme in the movie: It is generally speaking about living life to its fullest. There is a bit of tragic backstory closely related to this, with Vinterberg's daughter dying shortly before the movie's making. And as this movie is dedicated to her, it does a justified job of giving the audience a bit of nudge to reflect on their lives.The camera and editing were fantastic and especially the (drunk-)acting was flawless and felt realistic.As a fellow European I was familiar with the drinking games and occasions shown here and found it very relatable to my country. But to international audiences this may seem exaggerated, which it is not. Alcohol is a major part in social life and especially in one's youth: the legal drinking age is at 16-18 in Europe.While I think the Best International Feature Film Oscar is deserved, I'll have to rate this movie a bit lower than Vinterberg's outstanding masterpiece "The Hunt" nonetheless. I have mainly two points of criticism.The premise is of course not very realistic. Four middle-aged highschool teachers would not agree to start teaching with a slight buzz and later up the game even more, all as a social experiment. I think this is where audiences could get the impression they are about to watch a comedy - which it is not. In fact there are only a couple of laughs being had in the movie.Yet, there is enough motivation to some of the characters that I am willing to suspend my disbelief. Actually the setting at a school job is a brilliant choice, since these aging teachers are confronted with youth sitting in front of them every day. And you really get that they would suddenly think "Damn, how did we get here?"*SPOILERS*And my second criticism comes to the predictability. It was foreseeable that their actions would backfire for the second act after everything seemed to be rosy for a while. Despite assuming where this was going the movie still surprised me with a couple of gut punches. Again, not a comedy.And despite how bad things got, I enjoyed that the movie did not just stick with the preachy message "See? This is what alcohol does!" It rather showed us a spectrum of how different people can get affected differently.First, I was not sure if I liked the fast tonal shift in the end. Bute the more I think about the ending the more I like it. Because the funeral of their friend could be the final wake up call to the other characters. To get their shit together and quit for good. Instead, we see that even a funeral (of an alcoholic) is yet another occasion to raise our glasses for a toast. It serves as a mirror for our society.Overall, "Another Round" is not an excuse for drinking nor a lecture advising against drinking but rather an inspiration to live your life with a certain easygoingness. And alcohol as a catalyst can not solve all of our problems.

reviews.review_title: An Ambiguous Love Letter to Booze
reviews.content: Another Round is a 2020 Danish drama from director Thomas Vinterberg. It stars Mads Mikkelsen, Thomas Bo Larson, Magnus Milang, and Lars Ranthe. The film follows these 4 as a friend group of high school teachers that set off on an experiment to test a theory that humans naturally have a Blood Alcohol Content that's 0.5% too low. Oh you Danish people. I found this film extremely entertaining.And it WAS so entertaining from the get go. The opening scene of Another Round drew me right in from the start and the camera work was a big part of that.I have a pretty low tolerance for egregious shallow depth of field in film. It just comes off like a cheap trick to me for some reason. This film did it right. Another Round used focus like any part of a film should be used - as a thematic tool. It's a fairly simple connection - moving in and out of focus depending on how coherent your character is - but the cinematographer for this film did it with restraint and artfulness to the point that u was swooning over it by the 2nd act.That said, the time it took to get to that 2nd act felt like nothing. This film flew by, even at two hours long. The plot is just such a fascinating concept that I lost track of time right along with the characters.Another Round is a cautionary tale that knowingly qualifies itself. I think people will interpret it differently depending on their background, but that's my interpretation of the ending.A cautionary tale without being a lifetime film, a celebration of alcohol without a blind eye to the morning after, and an unclear message that allows you to draw your own conclusions. I loved Another Round.8/10.

reviews.review_title: Humorous drama with heady Scandinavian backgrounds
reviews.content: Simply speaking, the film shows us what happens to middle-aged men when they didn't party enough in their youth. What starts as an innocent and funny alcohol experiment for four schoolteachers ends up leading to a whole baggage of all sorts of consequences in their lives.Sure, the story is much deeper than that: the characters don't only have fun while getting drunk and communicating but also take another perspective on their existence and even reassess some of its aspects. The heroes themselves seem very human: to the extent that they behave quite annoyingly at times, especially when you expect them to act firmly and decisively, whereas they drown in their alcoholic passiveness instead.As a huge bonus to the four friends' drunk adventures the film skillfully portrays details of Danish school life and some cultural aspects of Danish lifestyle overall. When talking about Scandinavia there are always images of natural beauties springing to mind, and the work proves it right: the sea, forests and accurate greenery here and there - all fits into the narrative well.As a result, the film turns up to be a wonderful tragic comedy giving its spectators not only reasons to laugh and feel ashamed of its drunk characters' behavior every now and then but also experience sadness and tranquility when watching the dramas of their lives unfolding against the background of heady Scandinavian nature.

Although flawed at times, the overall message is very important. This story, although not realistic at times is an important one to see. The acting is perfect, and the filmmaking is great. I recommend it if you are someone who can oversee small nitpicks.

reviews.review_title: The Three-dimensional core of Druk and views of freedom
reviews.content: Vintemberg's Druk reflects on practices of the self regarding the efforts and techniques against the weathering loop that life can turn to. These techniques, and, otherwise, methods or practises, constitute a certain form of liberation, which must not be mistaken with liberty, or, even more, with freedom. Vintemberg emphasizes the difficutly and perplexity of freedomness, while he captures the anti-social rawness of unprocessed liberation.More specifically, the experiment conducted by the company of our middle-aged men is an attempt to reactivate social and working abilities, also abilities conserning marriage and fathering. Through an antithesis scheme, Vintemberg stresses that freedom may constitute a state of being, only if it is deeply bonded with other spheres of life. Druk develops on the significance of (i) marriage and fathering (ii) efficiency at work and (iii) a cycle of friends and collegues, as for in order to show that the wounded self/individuality can remend, as long as practises of the self are framed and, therefore, difended by these three, beyond individuality, dimensions of being.Druk is about forgotten capabilities, slowly destructed, and the dangerous possibility of re-inventing them.Reinvention is presented as a procedure that can easily lead to failure if it is to be a lonely one. That is what is extracted from Tomi's tragic end, in constrast to Martin's different conclusion.Vinteberg calls as to reflect, alongside with himself, on contemporary means of freedom and the terrifying powers/factors that run against it.

reviews.content:
This is a movie with another great acting performance from Mads Mikkelsen and others, and with an excellent cinematography, but it also contains a deeply flawed argument. Whereas Thomas Vinterberg wished for a celebration of life, he achieved a glorification of alcohol.SPOILERS AHEAD
This is what the movie literally tells us: Drink alcohol to be at the top of your game professionally and in your personal life, and alcohol will even make you succeed at exams. Only a gross overconsumption of alcohol or alcoholism may be detrimental. May only though, as the best politicians and artists were alcoholics, and those who do not drink are Nazis... The woman subjected to alcohol fuelled domestic violence will take a glass of white wine when facing the abuser, before running back to him. Being sick from excessive alcohol consumption or running drunk into traffic is fun and harmless, and the final still image of the movie tells us that alcohol sets us free.Clearly the movie does not have the ambition to curb heavy drinking among Danish youth. It rather resemble the movie of a high-functioning alcoholic who would absolve himself of all guilt and even try to convince you that alcohol will make you a better person, and will make the society better too. The same movie could have been made with meth or heroin, which leaves little room for those of us who have chosen to remain true to themselves.

The film Druk, directed by the prolific Thomas Vinterberg, is formed because there is a theory that man is born with a lack of alcohol in his blood. This theory says that humans are born with an alcohol blood level that is 0.05% too low. The film follows Martin, a high school teacher, through a midlife crisis. He has problems with his wife and children at home and struggles with engaging his students in his lessons. Therefore, he and a few colleagues conducted a research paper about the consequences of raising your alcohol blood level and keeping it at the supposed sufficient level throughout the day. At first, the results start positive as they all become more engaged in teaching and become more open to ideas and activities. Then, they all begin to loosen up and see changes in their daily activities. After a while, some begin to feel the impacts of being constantly drunk and end up losing complete control. The film is out to comment on the danish drinking culture, which is becoming more and more out of control with binge drinking a regular part of life. For example, the film starts with an annual Danish tradition of a lake run consisting of teams of high school students who run around a lake while consuming an entire crate of beer, and vomiting can get two minutes deducted off your time. A report noted that 37% of Danes had "major regular alcohol usage", double the European average. With all this, Vinterberg wanted to bring this issue to light and to express that everything should be done in moderation, which can be seen as without drinking Martin and his colleagues went through life without any joy, while with too much alcohol they could not only lose loved ones but also to some extent themselves.

The tried and worn tropes of a beat down high school teacher needing to inspire his kids, a group of grown men feeling like their lives are past, and a man slowly on the way out of his marriage are all present but in this case it isn't a bad thing. It's not a bad thing not just because they're done "well" or "correctly", but because the writers and director understood what was behind those tropes and had something to share with them. They were a part of a bigger message than just making a movie that will make money, and that's something that can be rare today. And on top of the plot lines being purposeful and meaningful they were handled incredibly well I'm terms of coherence and cohesion. They don't baby you and explain everything, but it all fits together and loose ends aren't stuck straggling behind at the end trying to play catch up. An incredible message about MINOR SPOILER (if you don't want the themes to be spoiled) not just and drinking itself, but our capacity to fall as people and the meaning that gives to our lives. I absolutely loved this film.

reviews.review_title: Druk is another impactful and entertaining piece by thomas vinterberg
reviews.content: As a tribute to the premise of this film. I am reviewing this movie drunk. I have drunk one cup of gin and 3 cups of whiskey, hopefully thats around the 0.5% blood alcohol level that's significant to the point of this film. This film, like many of other Vinterberg's films, is drenched with realism and emotions as he effectively presents a family drama with the comedic premise of a group of goons drinking to the point of 0.5% BAC (blood alcohol content) to see if it betters their "social and professional performance". This film has the most visually appealing cinematography in Vinterberg's filmography (considering that I have only seen the Celebration and the Hunt HAHAHHAH). Everything you love about Vinterberg is present here, the realistic acting, the constant handheld yet effective shot composition present, the awkwardness and the unsettling mood that permeates the concepts that Vinterberg explores. In my interpretation, this film is exploring whether it is good/right to have a form of escapism for one's reality in order to improve one's life as a whole. The commentary on alcoholism is just superficial. This movie is examining inherently flawed characters that have made long-lived mistakes in their lives that have made them miserable, and they are striving for a solution to change it, and questionably rationalize it with the scientific foundation of Skaaderud's theory when it can be easily seen as an excuse to drink alcohol to evade life's challenges and relish an out-of-world sensation only possible with the elusive effects of booze.While at times the presentation of its message and thematic concern may seem obvious or pandering, it effectively showcases rich characterization from the likes of Mads Mikkelsen and others like Thomas Bo Larsen & Magnus Milang. It also alludes to and showcases everyday conflicts that resonates with pretty much everyone: the sense of inadequateness and the loss of interaction in long term relationships. It may not be as subtle as his other masterpieces, but to me it is a delectable addition to his repertoire. I strongly recommend this to the fans of his work. And if you are not one, you should watch this and then watch the Hunt, so that you would realize what a BEAST this Danish filmmaker is in his own right.In my drunken stupor, I shall now end my review. Hopefully this review is enough to intrigue you. If not, I shall make another review while sober to attract more attention MUAHAHAHA.

Mid Life Crisis, we all deal with it in our own ways, American Beauty, Kevin Spacey buys a red car and works at a burger place to affix his youth, John Travolta and co decide to ride to the pacific coast on their bikes to renew their life with connotation and exploration in Wild Hogs and much like Edgar Wrights, At Worlds End, the film in question here uses alcohol has a principal promoter to get some lost characters to revamp, remember and recharge their much needed mundane lives with a spark of meaning.Thomas Vinterberg, Danish director makes his most personal film yet, a film that suffered tragedy in the first week of production that in no doubt flickered the energy seen in this movie from the vision and panache depicted and at the centre of it, a career high performance from fellow Dane, Mads Mikkelsen who conveys the everyday man's image to precision and the in depth emotions within, expressively shown in every part of his acting that comes to a theatrical release at the end of the movie.For a Danish audience, this is the all-star cast, the major league players are all on show here, for an American, or western audience we are very invested from the reputation of their past collaboration of the hunt back in 2012, a stunning success that has certainly raised bars and expectations for this film originally titled Druk, which is Danish for Bender a film that certainly peaked awareness from its subject matter, a film that we know has the potential to deliver no matter what the plot may be because of the team behind it.Another Round, has it is called In America tells the story of The banal reality of four high school teachers in Denmark who finds a cause to rediscover the presence of their live again instead of languishing about what could of or might or been in the past. After dinner one evening, the four friends talk about a theory through sociable conversation slash banter about humans that can perform better with a small amount of alcohol frequently present in their system.Giving themselves the unjustified reasons to do this like how famous drunks performed better like Churchill and Hemingway and With absolutely nothing to lose and with the shock of smiling and being present and comfortable with the lives again, they take on this theory together and decide to stay low level drunk all day whilst observing and recording the results: at first with some optimistic paybacks but then eventually soon starts to spiral into a learning curve about life, purpose and reason.The heart of this movie is the characters that have to go through some sort of obstacle to actually re-discover that what they had was enough and suitable for them. The normal construction of emotions is if you are at a limbo stage in life, aka a midlife crisis, a psychologist tells people that you are naturally looking for a spike, a spike you know will shoot up, like buying a car or riding to the coast on a bike, then drastically and slowly go down below what your limbo state was and at that low point, you then start to regret and realise that your life wasn't that bad at that limbo state, meaning quit simply that your normal routine life is actually everything you need and want it to be if you allow yourself to be in the present.It is a worthwhile message that this film is cleverly trying to make people realise, a message that isn't articulated in American Beauty or Wild Hogs, where they simply focus on the spike but not the repercussions of the quick decent from this initial spike.The idea of finding purpose again in life is an important arc of a story done in many films, but what Vinterberg is exposing here is the literally movie interpretation of what bugs bunny does to trick the Tune Squad in Space Jam by giving them, the special stuff drink, and making them perform a lot better, tapping into that unfilled potential, unlocking it and then later realising that the special stuff was the just water, it was also part of their DNA to do it, and it just needed a scapegoat, if you will, to release and even change the way your mindset works. Obviously, with four people doing this, we have different experiences, different mind-sets has the film goes along. Completely fascinated and convinced that this theory works, they decide to up the dose of alcohol level and in this is where the lessons and mistakes are happening, where the spike starts to gradual come down.The tone is exceptional, it finds a nuance place between hilarious and melancholic, ever-changing our opinions of this experiment has the movie goes. What starts to be one thing, deviants to something completely unexpected and thus creates this enigmatic story to follow where we don't know what's around the next corner because this journey, rightfully so, is out of control, in the hands of the over-indulgence of alcohol and the newly sparked victims of this experiment.It's high concept, its daring and the darkness is well placed in a movie that is at the same time, amusing.The ending of the movie is in no doubt shining the ever-needed light into a film that could be hidden by western audiences because of the unknown interest in Nordic films. The last scene, proving very meme worthy and high impact is a trailer on its own to promote the movie, the dance of life, the realisation of how precious and quick life can be and how important it is to be in the presence.Mads Mikkelsen an ex-dancer, beautiful orchestrates a physical message of a man finally discovering something after 40 year, the beauty of life of when you are in the present. He defines his character has something who has missed the train for life and has been on the platform waiting ever since, a beautiful visual metaphor for his circumstance at the beginning of the movie, one where unfortunately a lot of people can relate to and this is the market that Vinterberg chooses to explore very inversely than other commercial movies following similar story arcs.He does this again with the social impact of how a lie can spiral out of control with his past film with Mikkelsen in The Hunt and once again conveys another messaging on life escalating and the social impact of everyday things effecting your life. Vinterberg is clinical, a master of this trade and a soon to be household name, if he isn't already to the general broad audience which will put his names up there with Christopher Nolan and Denis Villneueve.A mid life crisis is simply an escape, just like films are but what makes Another Round seductively intriguing is the on the noes story of similarities an audience can easily relate to and completely understand the emotions the actors are performing which makes it not an escape but simply a realisation, a wake up call that life, of course is precious and being in the present is in fact the answer to any midlife crisis, a spike that will never go down but simply remain constant just like time, just like life and the sooner you are realise that, the happier you will be.

A great film centred around the role that alcohol plays in society. I was initially surprised when I read reviews describing the film as pro-alcohol. I personally thought the opposite.There were many thought-provoking moments in the film and I found myself reflecting on my own beliefs around alcohol consumption and habit formation, as well the responsibility that teachers carry. Take for instance, the scene when Lars Ranthe's character "Peter" was consoling the student, "Sebastian". Peter encourages Sebastian to drink alcohol to calm his nerves and help him pass his exam. Yes, he might have helped him pass the test, but he also taught Sebastian to avoid facing his problems and rely on alcohol as a crutch when faced with a challenging situation. Sebastian will unconsciously associate the good feeling he gets after passing the exam with the act of drinking the alcohol, forming a habit. Why do the hard work and face your issues head on when you can just take a drink? This led me to question the role of a teacher. Is teaching only about getting good grades for your students? Or is teaching really about leading your students to recognise their own strength and power and showing them how to deal with problems in a healthy way?

In my view, movie isn't about drinking as most people comment here. It wanted to show that we should enjoy and appreciate our beautiful lives, and we shouldn't be misled by routine or fears and thus to start looking easy escapes (alcohol is just one of many possible escapes) by forgeting that actually our life is really beautiful.
